For all rights, this is a very great game. But even so, its not such that deserve the too high of a rating it gets. The one thing and the only thing that I hate the most is the combat, and how jarring it is that as a SURVIVAL GAME, the best strategy to face enemies is to repeatedly hit and run multiple times. Yeah, there are 'other' ways to do it, but it is the most efficient way, and least resources consumed so you spend most of your combat time kiting with every enemy, be it bosses or the pigmen and such. After long, I just couldn't continue playing.  And so, downvote for balance purposes only, and please vote don't starve as labor of love.

well... were to start, my friends and I saw this in a sale a while back and thought we should give it a try, we went in blind.  yeaaaa, well we havent played anything else (or gone outiside) for 3 weeks now, its a strong addiction. let me give you the rundown, bassically i have one friend that gets sidetracked every five minutes to go "explore" thw world (ignoring all the dire things we need to do and against the teams will) he often gets near death although bribgs back some good loot. Next we have the friend that has a mild sexual relationship to our crock pots and often does not trek further out than 10 m before getting homesick, not gunna lie hes pretty useless, but he makes us a tonne of food a bit like a housewife. Then we have friend number 3, who has recently been diagnosed with mild accute uselessness syndrome  symptoms: standing aroun the camp the entire day moaning about having nothing to do being useless dying abmormerly  he has set the record of dying the fasted as possible and he is bassically the definition of a noob.  Then there me, the one that tries to frantaclly pull everyone back together and to be honest im the only reason were at day 27 (3rd attempt) and not dead.  the morale of the story is not play with idiots.  all in all i reccomend this game highly and you should give it a try, but dont play with idiots.

Been some time since I started playing this one, huh? Nevertheless The Don't Starve Together is STILL one of those survival games, that are Actually cool. Graphics are unique Klei style. It's like a comic book/video game crossover. Every monster, character and even object has unique feel to it, as well.  Gameplay isn't just "another survival game" thing. It may seem simple at first, maybe even repetitive. But I still enjoyed farming stuff and repeatedly punching spiders in the face with a homemade Ham Bat (yes, iconic DS's weapon of choice), just for fun. Also, one of the hardest things in this game is planning "What do I do next?" stuff and being time efficient. And, of course, dealing with your friends absorbing fridge's contents, faster than you fill it. I guess you can't even free yourself from your silly buddies when going into virtual world. But it's not like I didn't enjoy having an extra challange, heh.  Audio fits well, it gives different tone to each of the Seasons present in game, e.g. Winter feels rather sad, Spring is a bit jumpy (in it's own positive purport). Of course, there couldn't be a good ol' Boss Fight, without the good ol' Boss Theme. Indeed, this game provides you with some encouraging tunes for such occasions.  Story. Yes, this game has a rather impressive lore for a survival game. Most of it is present outside of the game, though. Still worth doing a lil' research. DST's plotline is separate from Don't Starve (Alone)'s.  ------TL;DR------ Pretty decent survival game with unique artstyle, music, nice lore and Meatballs. Takes some time to get good at it (and lots of deaths). And Together implies you'll be able to get some friends to play with OR you'll have to use all of your patience for public plays. But most importantly, prepare to Don't Starve! P.S. If you read everything, then here's a Huge thanks to you! Have a nice day Now includes yearly time-limited events. Devs are real good bois

Bosses that offer up quite a challenge, and can't exploit them to win to easily, but yet not too hard to figure out how to win. There are also many different creatures who will all act differently depending on what character you are.  Of course, the beautiful graphics that the creators obviously spent a long time perfecting. For the price of fifteen dollars, definetly recommend buying this game, be it jsut for yourself, or to play with your friends. This game is plently of fun for a very long time.

Long story short my friend getting silk got killed by spider queen (dont ask ok) and my other friend was being attacked by treeguard. My friend managed to kill some spiders with his axe so i got 2 glands but my friend was low on health from treeguard  and i didnt know who to save. I ended up saving the guy dead, and we helped my other friend with treeguard. Day 2: Ok so we werent that good at the game and we decided to go into a cave but i was left behind in case of emergency. My friends didnt have the tools to survive in the cave and died from a variety of different things (earthquake, bunnymen, tentacles, etc) and i was last one alive. wow. Day 7: OK i was doing good on my own until i realized my sanity was low from the ghosts. I died from my own insanity and gg no re.       A year after buying:   Day 26: Me and the same group of friends were doing really well and decided to plan how we were gonna defeatdeerclops. We had plenty of food and supplies and we were fine on warmth.  Day 30: We beat deerclops but one of our friends died. The other died from cold/spiders trying to save said friend. This game takes the sheer survival awesomeness of Don't Starve and puts it in multiplayer format.  Pros: All the server formatting menu options have a defined, useful purpose You can create a server for just yourself and your friends if you want to All the items have been rebalanced for multiplayer (i.e. griefing is a lot harder now) Collectables don't take a trillion years to get The GUIs are super easy to use The dialogue has jokes that actually make sense Predictive lag compensation  Cons: Resources can become bit scarce on a public server  Controls can become a bit convoluted and hard to remember  Overall I recommend this game for anyone who has either played the original DS or is looking for a multiplayer challenge.      P.S. KLEI PLEASE MAKE SHIPWRECKED TOGETHER!!!!!!!!!!

A very enjoyable game for people new to Don't Starve Together or returning players from Don't Starve. Sacrificing some content/modding abilities from the single player version to have fun, multiplayer style. The more players working to not starve, go insane or die together, the better i'd say.  In my personal experience Autumn is a good starting point and is quite an enjoyable season because in this season the players must get busy in preperation for winter and giants to come.   Winter hits, at first there is a bit of struggle, we hunt, travel, then gameplay becomes quite boring until the Deerclops spawns. (mostly because my friends and I feel their isn't much else to do at that moment but to wait out Winter. But that may be just our ignorence.)  Spring, is a pretty annoying season. Food does not dry while raining, periods of rain are really long, and your insanity drops very fast. But thanks to heat and items such as umbrellas i feel spring is pretty balenced.  (Fighting the Moose boss was no walk in the park.....especially since we got Rekt'd by the little gooslings........)  Summer, ah summer, the season of rage quit and throwing your computer out the window.   Overall I would give this game a 100/10 a very fun and intersting game and I look foward to more updates! :)

The pinnacle of survival games, which actually requires players to survive. Normally survival games are just, start off with nothing in the wilderness, kill everything else and build a castle. This game requires players to actually work to stay alive and build a settlement to further aid in their survival creating a highly unique and innovative experience. Unlike many other games, it also uses a very stylized and intricate art style as well as having a very well written although unspoken plot.  The game features a healthy amount of randomization which makes each world relatively individual and fresh, and while the combat system is simple it manages to still feel satisfying. While including a lot of grinding like most survival games, in this one it barely feels like a chore because the player is constantly working to gather the supplies to immediately build something new. There are only a few instances where the reward for time spent is very far off, what the player chooses to do is rewarded or punished very quickly.  The game however makes no effort to teach the player anything, which results in both a more refreshing experience and an unfair one. Players will die numerous times to things they had no way of preparing for without looking up a guide, which potentially involves numerous world resets and lost progress. It does not feel as bad as normal trial-and-error psuedo difficult gameplay, but it still can be a problem. Especially when the game will continue to dish out unfair situations even after players are experienced; as there is always one more thing players did not know, which they are punished for not knowing.  Finally, the game also has problems with balance. As there are many overly effective tactics players can use to make survival much easier. The game puts so much effort into being punishing and unforgiving yet there are random aspects of the system which are far more lenient to the player for no reason. Which means if players enjoy difficulty the game hypocritically makes certain things far easier then they should be, just because. Various content in the game is also underpowered or overpowered in general, and so there are certain items players will default to using a lot and others they barely will. This even including the playable characters.  While the multiplayer side of the game is exceptionally enjoyable, when in a good team, the public multiplayer is still susceptible to griefing. Although after a couple years some counters to griefing were finally patched in. There are also various bosses in the game which have their health scaled to ridiculous amounts in anticipation for multiple players being present, and so playing the game alone or with a small group will make certain fights unfairly challenging without the use of a health scaling mod.

Not so much a review, more of a few suggestions I wanted to make...  1) When you first boot up the game you are met with a screen with, besides other things, a "play" button and a "quit" button. Obviously in this window, clicking the quit button quits the game.  And the play button takes you to the main menu.  Now, at this point after pressing the play button, you're met with a "logging in" screen with an optional "offline mode" button on it.  Couldn't that be an option within the main menu itself rather than being automatic? Because my next issue is to do with the main menu itself.  My biggest issue is that the main menu ALSO has a "quit" button that quits the game. Basically, I think either you remove the redundant opening screen or you make the quit button go back to it.  Like I said a few lines ago, the "logging in" thing should be optional, because if I'm to slow to click "offline" then I'd have to quit and reopen the game again which, in my opinion, is a little convoluted.  Also, I don't know if it's just my computer, but the resolution seems to be terrible for me (1366 x 768) Is it because the game is dealing with an unknown shape and it's being squished unnaturally?

This is a truly amazing peace of art. Go into the wild looking for recources as you struggle to survive. Days getting shorter, nights getting longer just waiting for the souls to get you. Earn character customizations while you're sitting near your science station crafting items to help you. Invite friends, so you can truly don't starve together! This game will get you addicted to it for hours upon hours restarting, or maybe surviving. The art will amaze you, and the characters will to. Even when you get bored you have the option of mods to cure that boredom, and you will get up in the morning, and wonder why it's already 3:00AM.          Ok so now really, this game is all about, well... Surviving of course with friends. You get spawned, then immedietally have to search for supplies because night is coming, and it's coming fast. Then you forget to look at the clock, and it's night... First restart. Then you find these pigs, and are excited because they help you survive. Until... The green pigs come, and destroy you. Then you get way further just for you to realise... WAIT IT'S WINTER?!?! Another restart. You're prepared for winter this time, then you survive for quite a bit longer. Then... The unexpected happens. You're house lights on fire because it's... Guess what? Summer! Then you have to restart building, or restart because you're in the flames of your burning house. I think this is a warning for all new players.. Simply watch out for the cycle. When it's winter try to be prepared with a coat before hand, when it's summer put fans near the wood at your house, and you. Then all frustration ends, and you're back to normal, and happy again... Until the cycle starts again, and night happens faster.                                                                   There's lots of pros to this game, so heres a few.                                                                                                       PROS -Art -Comes with an extra copy -Play with friends -Online -Survival physics -Somewhat challenging                                                                                                      CONS -WAIT?!?!?! IT'S WINTER AGAIN ALREADY?

First off, it'll say this review was posted in 2017. Well I've changed my mind at this point and time. Just... read if you want to find out the horrible truth.. This game. Oh boy. Don't Starve Together is an amazing game, with developers that care so much about the game that they don't patch bugs that have been in for 4 years and literally break the ga- heh, anyways, it's still a very enjoyable experience overall, but I had just experienced the most disturbing thing I'll possibly ever see. I absolutely cannot recommend this game just due to the chance that this might happen to anyone else.  Ok, so, there is a character in the game named Wigfrid who is a battle warrior and mostly has to hunt for food. So I was just hunting right, in the middle of a desert, just waiting for that delicious koalefant to soon be in my stomach. But, well, there is also a 5% chance something much more terrifying can spawn. And I was one unlucky warrior that night. The "Varg" (swedish for Wolf) is a massive Wolf that summons its other wolves to aid it in combat. It's truly an overwhelming enemy. Well, before I knew it, I was completely surrounded by hounds. But something was wrong.  The Varg deeply stared at me, and the hounds just kept barking. Usually after about 3 barks they attack. Well, all I had at the moment was like, some grass and twigs in my pocket and the Wigfrid character's battle spear and battle helmet. The hounds suddenly just darted in and carried everything I had away in their mouthes... keep in mind this whole time I was alone and in the middle of a desert. Well, within just a few more seconds, they tore off my skin "Shadow Armor". It's just a skin so not actual armor. Anyways, not much longer I was tackled by the mighty Varg itself. I knew I should have died at that moment. But life just kept going at me, huh?  You can probably imagine what happened right after that. So much was going on, I, I didn't know what to do. It was only about 30 seconds in that I had the entire scence scarred into my mind. Some time later my character just completely got knocked out, which I'm assuming was from deleriousness from the extreme pleasure. My character woke up the next morning with all the stuff I had next to me. Well, my hunger was full at least. I came back to the base very ashamed that day. Pretty much everyone laughed at me, some took screenshots. It was horrid, but nowhere near as horrid of what had happened yesterday. Sigh. Even Wigfrid was groggy, started looking like she was crying later.   Well, all in all, this game is what happens when developers make something good and decide to completely ruin it from just one thing. And yes, I know, you do not have to hunt in the game. But at one point in time, you'll go hungry and no one has food. It'll be your only chance really. And just the chance, that 5% chance of getting that image burned into your head. That's something scary.  If you do decide to get this game anyway, please. Just contradict the title. It's much better to embarrasingly starve than... I don't even want to remind myself of it anymore. Well, bye. Please, save yourselves from the Varg.

This game is absolutely fantastic.  From the art direction, to the music, to the mechanics, it's fun in every aspect.  I have played this series a long time, and Don't Starve Together was the iteration it always needed.  Don't Starve was BEGGING for multiplayer.  This game should be extremely fun with friends, to the point that I begged and wheedled everyone I knew to get it.  It's going to be amazing, I said.  I put a lot of my credit on the line with them; at my age, you don't have many friends, and about 10% of those still play video games.  I honestly wish I hadn't, because currently, Don't Starve Together is basically unplayable.  The rubberbanding gets worse and worse, the lag is atrocious.  Even on home network, playing with my girlfriend, it gets to be that you have to continuously restart the game until you don't feel like playing anymore.  We finally got everyone together online, my friend who more or less owns a supercomputer and 250mb down/50mb up connection hosted the game.  Within an hour, we were restarting the game every few minutes.     I am so goddamn embarrassed that I recommended this game to everyone, and we all got together for a night of playing, and couldn't enjoy ourselves, even with only 4 players.  If you read the reviews, this rubberbanding and lag issue has been going on since the release of the game, and the developers don't seem to be doing anything to resolve it.  It's not the mods, it's not our computers, it's not the connection...  the problem lies in the code.  Seriously, Klei Entertainment, get your shit together.  Seriously.  This is totally unacceptable.

Okay I think I have played the game long enough to finally write a review on this.  Well since they offer a free copy of the game with the oringinal purchase of the game for 14.99 I gifted it to my friend and we've been playing it together ever since,this game is tremendous amounts of fun with a friend,probably even more fun if you have multiple friends to play it with!   So here's a lil story of our adventures together.  As I SabinSaberWolf and his trusty friend by his side we stared at this world bravely with no fear,but yet to know what the world actually had in stored for us. Our first adventure together we began trotting along the road and decide to make basecamp near a pond,we seen no frogs as it seemed to be deserted we ignored the fact there were two other ponds near by as we gathered supplies on day 3 we returned back to camp to live through the night by our warm fire as the morning soon came,least did we know we were attacked by a frog army,we ran and ran,but they wouldn't quit chasing us as we refused to give up our home! We decided to fight back,but soon did I notice my friend had fallen by the frog meanace! I refused to leave her there as I decided to fight the frogs to the death! I managed to kill one frog,but sadly the frog nation proved to be way more powerful than we could have ever imagined.  Our second adventure. Crazed out of our minds about what has just happened with the frogs we decided to play it more carefully and on our toes! Prepared for the frog nation as to whether it would attack again! We made a camp on the edge of the world where it was safe from the devilish frogs! As we remained safe and sound near rabbits.as a few days past we ate through all our supply of food and was forced to explore the world more in to the depths of the unknow,as we saw a few harmless bees we thought nothing of it,until we soon saw about 100 more nests as most of em' turned out to be evil bee nests,we quickly ran through the unknown to try and get away from the evil bees as they kept coming and coming as there were nests everywhere! There was no escape! They murdered my friend in cold blood as I knew I was outmatched with only my axe,as we only came there for some food as peaceful travelers! Least did I know I ran in to a dead end with no escape in sight as I stood there cornered by the evil bees with my axe in hand ready to fight to the death and for the honour of my friend! I swung and swung my axe with no mercy as I managed to murder two of the evil bees,but the rest still managed to over power me as I fell to the ground feeling my body getting cold from the multiple bee stings as the whole world soon turns to black as I awaken as a ghost and see my friend there staring at me as now we spend together forever as peaceful ghosts,but yet did we know,we were enterring in to a whole new world!  Adventure Three There isn't much danger in this adventure we managed to build up a camp with a hay wall built all around us with traps for bunnies n a farm growing our food together learning new things through our marvelous science machine,as we have not met anything to fear yet,we are living a pretty good life together surviving day by day,keeping each other sane as we possibly could. We're living the dream for now,everything is going so well for us now,is this really our happy ever after? Or is there something out there in the darkness stalking us? We try not to worry,but we have no idea what is haunting us,but we insure to be prepared for what ever life throws at us now! We musn't fail as this must be our time!  That's all of our adventures summed up to a point.  So in my opinion I give this game a perfect 10/10 one of the best games I have ever played in a long while that is co-op with a survival aspect. Also hopefully my lil stories didn't leave you a bore.

I like this game alot, the fact that it comes with an extra copy to send to your Friend is really nice. It's really fun, and the art style is great. Would recommend this to all of my friends.  Pros: *Runs on pretty much any computer. I tested this on a computer with an i3 with intell HD Graphics 2000, runs really well. *Great fun. Don't look stuff, find out how to make a base, trust me, it's more satisfying. *Comes with an extra copy to give to a friend. Cons: *Requires making an account with a third-party. In order to play, you must create an account on their site. *To join a public server, you often need some form of add-on or mod.

Started playing this game with my roomate and both of us were disappointed.  Neither of us played the single player version.  There really wasn't anything "fun" about this game.  During the day, you feverishly scramble across the landscape grabbing all kinds of stuff that might be useful.  Night is fairly short, and you pretty much sit there by the fire, feverishly cooking food and getting as much crafting done as possible.  Then it's back to feverishly trying to find stuff around the world.  There really is no "calm," at least for a relatively new player.  You're always slowly dying from starvation, too fast in my opinion.  A feverish pace is required for survival which, as a n00b, makes it difficult to explore the different, potentially cool stuff you could craft or explore.  Combat is terrible, and it's difficult to click on your enemy.  The game discourages fighting and experimentation by making death very punishing.  You have to find a special stone somewhere in the world or craft a relatively advanced meat effigy to resurrect one of you.  Nothing about the game is very rewarding.  Collecting stuff is rather mundane.  The traps are whatever.  Crafting something like an umbrella when it rains is just a way to die slower.  You don't build a cool house or anything like that - you're stuck with basic and advanced versions of an outdoor camp site.  BUT YOU MUST SURVIVE!!!!! ?? But why? What's the goal?  Survival? Okay, but that by itself isn't very fun.  Can I make a badass mansion or a cart track like in Minecraft?  No...  Do I get a well-designed, dynamic, and intense scavenging/trading experience like in This War of Mine? No........  Okay, do I get varied and interesting weapons, armor, and equipment like in Terraria?  No.....  Do I get a deep sense of human fear and connectedness, like in Day Z, when I'm not sure if someone will help me survive or literally kill me?  No.  Play another survival game.

I was originally bagered by a friend to download this game so we could play together.  All I can say is, i'm glad I didn't spend my own money on this game.  To sum it up, you run around as different selectable cartoon characters- each with their own strength in "something" and each with their own particular weakness.  EX: Willow gains sanity points from fire, however if she becomes insane begins to freeze to death.  EX 2: Wendy has a ghost sidekick (her sister) who can fight for/with her. She can aggro and tank enemies, and deal damage. However Wendy herself has some of the lowest base attack damage in the game and has a hard time killing without her ghost.  The goal is simple: To survive. You must run around and gather food, collect materials, and build items to help you survive through each season or die. (EX: you need to gather items and craft warm clothing for the winter season or risk freezing to death). You also have to fight with the strange creatures that inhabit the land, some friendly but many of which will try to kill you for no reason. There are also boss fights at set intervals in the game, usually one for each season.  HOWEVER.  Why am I not giving this game a positive review?  Honestly this game loses its novelty very quickly. Once you survive through all the seasons at least once, you have gathered basically everything you need to survive those four seasons again. (The seasons loop).   The only real task you will have is basically gathering from then on, as you've probably explored 99% of the map by the end of the  four seasons. You'll run around just restocking on food, if you haven't already created your base camp next to the beefalo (some of the best source of meat in the game) and relocated all the tree's, saplings, and berry bushes you need right around your camp. Although you will have to leave to gather ores, as rocks are the only thing unrelocatable for convinence.  The only real replay value in this game is if you decide you want to try to survive with a different character, which will require some slight tweaking on how you approach surviving but not by extremely too much unless your the mime guy who basically dies to everything.   So sure, feel free to survive until day 100.....day 200.....day 300. It's just gonna be a repeat of all the crap you spent doing the first runthrough of the 4 seasons. Nothing new really occurs.  The Caves BETA is a very nice addition to the game, Kudo's to the developers on it. It does add another intresting layer of depth to the game. Instead of trying to survive on the base map you can try to survive underground in the caves, which poses a whole new set of challenges, and different creatures/plants/objects inhabit the caves below. That being said once you conquer the caves your back to the original rinse and reuse and repeat problem as stated above.  FINAL VERDICT:  First 3-4 playthroughs: 7.5/10  Replayability: 3/10  S/N: Im serious guys, It got to a point where me and my friend  legit had nothing else to do and conquer in the game that I started arranging berry bushes and tree's for fun for about 2 hours. Save yourself the sanity.

[h1]Don't Starve Together: 2 hours in review[/h1]  [b]Summary[/b]: A quirky open-world survival game that will trick you into a false sense of security with its Burton-esque art and goofy mannerisms and then punish you greatly by the end of night one.  In a sea of hyper-realistic survival sims, DST is a welcome breath of fresh air. Set in a strange little world that looks as if it was ripped from Tim Burton's mind, the game has little in the way of background. In the Single Player (Don't Starve) you wake to a man telling you that you had better find food before nightfall. No context, no other back story, just get out there and survive. In DST, you and your friends emerge out of a portal and set out to explore and survive. Lots of little laughs can be had at your character's comments and observations as well as the silly little things going on in the world.  DST doesn't seem brutal at first. There are cute little sprites for characters in the pseudo 3D world that bound about. Frogs, bees, rabbits, and a number of other creatures move around the world with you. Flowers grow and bloom, trees stand tall, and berry's hang from bushes inviting you to eat them. There are  few goofy moments as you run about collecting things, crafting thing, but this is a bit of a facade and perhaps your first enemy in the game. This game is surprisingly tough. It reminds me of Minecraft and DayZmod before there were guides up on the net. You get out, you run around, and maybe you attack something in hopes of food...then you die. You get out, you run around, and then it gets dark.....then you die. You get out, you run around, you survive the night and then you starve to death, or you run into some of the mechanical pig things that charge you, or you catch fire. As cute as it seems, it can be unforgiving. And when you die, you've got to have a buddy craft a heart to bring you back or you're stuck haunting around as a ghost.  Don't worry, though, its that challenging that's fun enough to keep you wanting more of it.  [b]The Good[/b]: The Atmosphere of the game is great. I love the Gothic, Burton-looking art style, and everything fits together very well. The game-play seems pretty balanced, and the crafting is handled quite easily; you don't have to put together complex patterns or obscure combos, everything is listed and what-not, which is good because you'll be a little more focused on surviving.  [b]The Bad[/b]: Its not for the easily frustrated. You'll probably have a good number of deaths in the first go of it. Some times the worlds spawn things you need early on in very rare quantities, and that can lead to you running around with nothing progressing for a while. You can fix this by customizing the set up for the server if you want.  [b]The Ugly[/b]: Finding spiders so you can craft the resurrection item sucks.  Great game, and with it being two for the price of one AND it comes with the Single Player....you can't beat it!

It felt like I was playing Minecraft for the first time again. A simple survival game with an art style that i've come to love. This game doesn't take a lot of skill to be really good at, but it takes a decent amount of knowledge. The more that you play this game the easier it is to survive in it. I found myself doing research after a play session to see if i could fix the mistakes in my last run. Hell, for the longest time i didn't know how to use maxwells book, and he is now my favorite character (minus mods). With mods this game is so much fun, because the art design is very unique, but simple enough for talented artists to draw in their own OCs with unique mechanics. The explanation of the Frontier Pack is pretty misleading, not very clear, and thus kind of useless. I already owned Don't Starve so I was just going to wait until it was free (if I understand what they are saying, although noone really seems to know). Then I saw the Frontier Pack that said you would buy Don't Starve and 2 copies of Don't Starve Together. For whatever reason, they decided that you can't take that particular copy of Don't Starve as a gift, so I just wasted money by buying the game I already have a second time, and STILL had to buy a THIRD copy to give to my friend. I think that's a bit excessive and pretty cheap. Maybe I just don't understand exactly how this works though? I didn't think it was unreasonable to think that I could use the 2nd copy of a game I already owned as a gift for a friend...  I know these reviews are supposed to be for gameplay, but right off the bat, that's a pretty frustrating issue. I shouldn't be confused about what I'm buying when I buy something. I read through the description more than once and also read the note they had for downloading it. Because of their poor advertisement and enclear writing, I've marked that I do NOT reccommend. HOWEVER, having played Don't Starve, I'm sure the gameplay is fine. If you do not own Don't Starve at all, this will probably be a very fun experience. My negative thoughts are solely based on how they handled people who already own the game. For everyone else, I do recommend this game.  If anyone else is considering getting the Frontier Pack, I hope this review was helpful.

I despise this stupid fucking game and I fail to see how anyone manages to eke the slightest bit of fun out of it. Don't Starve is an exercise in futility, a mindlessly frustrating "survival" experience brought to you by sadistic developers who punish the player through nonsensical mechanics and random catastrophe. Doing everything correctly won't save you. Something will always happen that destroys all of your hard work. You can learn from your experiences, but there will only be another one that kills you, and the developers are always busy inventing new ways to screw the player. Don't Starve was nonstop punishment for no good reason and Don't Starve together is the same cancer but with multiplayer. This franchise is total garbage and I await your stupid comments for my dissenting opinion.

Uh Not too sure what to write here so heres a recipe for Pancakes instead  Ingredients: 1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour 3 tablespoons sugar 1 tablespoon baking powder 1/4 teaspoon salt 1/8 teaspoon freshly ground nutmeg 2 large eggs, at room temperature 1 1/4 cups milk, at room temperature 1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract 3 tablespoons unsalted butter, plus more as needed  Now to make it 1. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg. 2. In another bowl, beat the eggs and then whisk in the milk and vanilla. 3. Melt the butter in a large cast iron skillet or griddle over medium heat. 4. Whisk the butter into the milk mixture. Add the wet ingredients to the flour mixture, and whisk until a thick batter is just formed 5. Keeping the skillet at medium heat, ladle about 1/4 cup of the batter onto the skillet, to make a pancake. Make 1 or 2 more pancakes, taking care to keep them evenly spaced apart. Cook, until bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, and the undersides are golden brown, about 2 minutes. Flip with a spatula and cook about 1 minute more on the second side. Serve immediately or transfer to a platter and cover loosely with foil to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining batter, adding more butter to the skillet as needed. 6. Procedure for adding fruit to pancakes: Once the bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, scatter the surface with sliced or diced fruit, or chocolate chips, nuts, etc. Flip with a spatula and cook for 1 minute more, being careful not to burn toppings.



I can think of only a few words for this game, "addicting" and "amazing".  This game has so much creativity in every place you look. Not only is it creative, it truly is an experience that is it's own game, Don't Starve Together, with the New Reign updates, addons, DLC, whatever you call them, they are great.  The normal Don't Starve was meant to be a lonely experience, but this takes something lonely and makes it pleasantly social.  It just works with the abilities of the different Characters interacting with eachother and complementing eachother.  This game is truely an experience you will never forget.  I bought this the literal day it hit open beta and I never, not even once regretted buying it.  And that is how you know that it is truly something magical.

[h1][b]A clear improvement to the already must-play original title![/b][/h1]  Don't Starve it's already great, complete and challenging enough by itself, now add friends that can mess up things and that you can always have a laugh with, simply perfect!  The love that Klei has for their games is clearly shown in this game, it's far beyond "Don't Starve Multiplayer Mode", as since it's launch the team working on the game has been updating and giving unique features and improvements for what feels like almost another game! And it can always get better with Workshop support!  25/15 [i]Would not allow people to play as Wes again![/i]

"Overwhelmingly Positive" There are several good reasons for why everyone rates this game well. While with the newer updates, it's getting harder for me to play (shitty computer), this game is still wonderful. Granted, in the beginning, a tutorial would've been lovely, and coming from me this means something considering how much I love exploring a game without the tutorial. If you're going to play, I recommend watching some Let's Plays or Tutorials. Now, onto the actual review;  This game is amazing, a lovely mix between 2D models in a 3D world, several bosses to keep you on your toes, and so, so many ways to die. Combined with several mods you can play, this game is hard to fall out of love with. Whether it being new bosses, new characters, or Klei's well made events, it's great fun to play. Want to become an almighty Spider Overlord? Well, become Webber! Want to demolish an entire ecosystem of trees and eventually get demolished by Treeguards, well... that can be any character... but hey, choose Woodie or Maxwell! Several characters for several play-styles, along with many bosses like the Spider Queen, Treeguards, Deerclops, Moose (accompanied with the deadly, yet cutely weird Moslings), even... a tiny Mushroom Tree... Huh... I feel like chopping it...  Anyway, away from the bosses, there are so many ways you can control this game. Believe it or not, starving is the least of your problems. Want to take up herding? We got Koalephants and Beefalo for you. Massive farming? Probably want to choose Wickerbottom for this, but from Berries to Dragonfruit, choose whatever you feel like growing. Just remember the several recipes if you don't want to get Smart Pot (mod). There are several things from Spider farming, Pig farming, Bee farming, plant harvesting, as well as fishing just to keep saturated. Each boss has their unique trait, along with many different ways to kite them. Pretty hard to kill a few of them with just some melee weapons. If you feel like it, you can even do Butterfly harvesting, cause Klei made a use for Butterflies! Just make sure you don't get too greedy. Unless you like weird demon Santa Clauses. With several mechanics, beautifully made worlds, and just the sheer difficulty of surviving a few hundred days, filled with hours of fun, this game is a heavy recommend from me.

I used to play this game with my friends quite often last year, around October. I loved DST, but it got, as everything does, boring eventually so we took a break. We have decided to try and play it again, but the lag makes it completely unplayable. It used to run just fine on both of our computers, but today it won't work on either of our computers. My friend was unable to find my world, and it took forever for me to find her game after she gave up. It was an infinite loading screen for her. Once we actually tried to get in the game DST just completely stopped responding and my computer froze for a few minutes before it crashed. Neither of our computers have run DST like this before, neither does it struggle so much with any other games. What happened? It used to be laggy, but it was still playable. Lately though it is impossible. Can't recommend a game that doesn't work. If the issue with the lag were to be fixed, I would most definitely recommend this game, but in it's current state I simply cannot.

I bought this game because of its excellent ratings and because I wanted a fun online coop experience.  The game feels polished generally works well.  However, I had a hard time as a newbie. The game didn't teach me how to play, and it's easy to die. I tried joining other games, but most of the players didn't talk to each other or help, so the co-op experience was poor too.  The game seems geared towards people who want to spend hours-and-hours on end working to survive in a single game. And it looks like it takes many days of playing and studying to learn the game well enough to play it half-decently.  So I found this game disappointing and not a good fit for what I was looking for.  Pros: * Nice graphics * Fitting music and sound * Runs well on my computer * The temporary "Gorge" event was fun and co-op focused  Cons: * Overhyped * Hard to find a good game to join * Online co-op was disappointing * Not newbie-friendly * Cannot pause * Game encourages playing for hours non-stop and is draining  So in conclusion, I think the game is overhyped and more of a niche thing. I feel the game would work better with local split-screen co-op with friends rather than joining pre-existing games online with strangers. Disappointed.

This is a game. and its as good as top down surivals get in the scheme of things. But it has led to a almost fatal blow to my friendship with the people i played this game with.  Now in the personality select screen there is a spider. this almost cute inocent spider cought my eye my two other friends picked the lumberjack and wilson. the start was uneentful until we discribed our starting items, one axe one nothing and one sack of spiders... i was so excited to think i could make my own web laden army of spiders and placed it next to our camp.   mistakes were made. after killing the lumberjack wilson put his foot down and pulled out his torch. i yell to him to stop the crazed look in his eye as he stumbled aimlessly twards my family i raised as my own. exchanging insults in the dead of night my spiders killed him as they burned. a new game was made  the next map. i felt betrayed and plotted behind his back, the spiderlings safe in my pouch. i wait till the time was perfect.  our lumberjack then screamed in horror. to their dismay a large ent camp into our camp as darkness fell over it. this was my time I quickly built the only torch and placed the spider in the middle of camp and sprinted into the darkness laughing as i heard my friends dieing yelling my name followed by words i wouldnt speak to my enemy.   this was 4 months ago. i just started talking to my friend again.... RIP spiders.

This game is horribly unbalanced. literally everytime my girlfriend and i play it. there is some catastrophic "ruining" of everything we build each and every time. you have to be into this kind a niche to enjoy this crappy game.  and if you are in the niche, then prepare to sink a WHOLE lot of time into it and get NO-where. I have played a little Don't Starve in the past.  It was a great game, but it got boring quick, as things got repetitive.  Playing with friends, on the other hand, makes things a lot more interesting.  Being the douchebag that I am, it is always fun to verbally abuse and mess with people.  At the moment, I play this game with a friend and some random kid that we have made into our slave, aka b*tch.  He does most of the work, such as gathering and crafting.  He also plays a robot, which are designed to be the slave to man.  Therefore, it is the perfect role for him.  As a man, I do the hunting.  I bring home the bacon, in this case, rabbits.  We also have a woman.  She is pretty useless.  All she does is pms and burn down all the berry bushes the robot worked so hard to tend and grow.  She tells me she didn't do it on purpose, but who can believe the words of a woman?  I know I can't.  I always make sure I am well fed and well rested.  The safety and wellness of the others matter very little to me.  With a full belly and rested body,  I do not have to fear anything.    I usually start my day with breakfast.  Its usually meatballs.  Who doesn't like meat and balls?  After a hearty unbalanced breakfast, I make my rounds, putting rabbits in chests.  They survive indefinitely with no food or water, until I murder them.  I collect seeds, poop, and materials along the way, but I never venture far.  I have my robot slave for the hard labor.  The woman also like venturing off.  At the end of the day, I come back and eat more meat.  Sometimes, I am nice enough to cook more for the servants.  Sometimes, I don't.  I enjoy it when they rush back as fast as they can, hoping there will be food there, while they are on the verge of death from starvation.  It makes things more interesting.  My servants are the best.  Without them, the game is nothing.  Using up materials and leaving them to wonder where all the gold went is hilarious.  They will most likely read this and hate me, but I am in charge of the server, so there is nothing they can do!

I don't think I've ever disliked a critically acclaimed game so hard. This game is the antithesis of good user experience, and you're forced to navigate through some of the most abhorrent UI design I've ever encountered in any game to survive in a world that is exceedingly unfair and unrelentingly ruthless.  If you somehow manage to survive for longer than a few days, you're forced to slog through endless obstacles that will have you saying "what the fuck did I just die to" over and over again. If you somehow manage to survive all the surprise mechanics that the game floods you with, you'll find that the gameplay is dull and repetitive with no real substance. It's like a game that begs the player not to play it.  I've given this game so many chances, but Don't Starve Together has definitely secured a position in my least favorite games ever created and due to its niche appeal, I wouldn't recommend it to the overwhelming majority of people.

It's okay, but I think it's slightly confusing. I came into this game, assuming it will be a game similar to games such as Terraria or Minecraft (which I love). What really made me come to this game was the artwork and style of the textures, which I think is amazing. Although, the gameplay is just too confusing to me. I doesn't really explain much and you would have to look up a lot of things to get to know the game. This also makes it quite disconnecting and doesn't really get me fully immersed into the game, so I quickly lose interest in the game. If you're looking for a survival open-world game with some challenging bosses, I think you should just get Terraria or even play Minecraft with mods.

I'm sorry but I just can't recommend this game. I've been playing it recently with my wife and son in co-op and it just feels like there was no real design plan, no project management or oversight. It feels like an artist came up with a bunch of art assets and threw them into a quickly built survival tutorial they found somewhere without giving any real thought to the game beyond "this seems like a cool idea!". Survival games generally swing between being too easy, and being an exercise in frustration; this one tends to the latter not because of complexity or genuine difficulty but rather arbitrary systems, poor feedback (in-game, on your actions and what you're doing) and a whole slew of bugs, issues and design flaws. I'm not going to go into specifics because quite frankly I've done enough for these developers by buying the game and giving them my money. Don't make the same mistake. Get something else to satisfy your survival urges.

Don't Starve is a great game.  Don't Starve Together is a horrible, terrible, bad game.  Day 1: Noobs take all the flint, pick all the flowers.  If you join 5 minutes late, good luck chopping a tree down in the first week.  Make a bird cage, someone picks the bird out of it, and eats it before dying, then they drain your sanity as a ghost.  Almost dead?  Make some food, wait for it to finish then die in front of the crock pot as someone else takes it.  Need rocks?  Too bad, someone already made a giant wall around the base.  Added bonus: You can't chase away the hands when you get low on sanity.  Current playstyle: Hoard grass, hoard flint, hoard gold, hoard everything, then die, leave, or just sit on it while others have nothing.  Make a beefalo pen?  someone will kill it, eat the meat.  Oh, and don't forget the frog rain.  Say you have 5 people in the game.  One noob decides to attack a frog, and they swarm, kill them, then another player, then another.  You, being the prudent one now have 3 ghosts draining sanity, rain draining sanity, frogs draining sanity.  I'm sure you were ready for it though right?  No gear? HEY GUYS LET'S FIGHT THE MOOSE GOOSE WITH NO GEARZ.  Lead it back to base, so the one with no gear can help.  Enjoy your sanity drain.  Are you Wigfrid?  Everyone kills those pesky bad stupid useless spiders and bees, so now you can't get free and easy sanity and hp boost from fighting them.  Playing this game is like being dropped in the woods with 5 random idiots.  They are the challenge.

My kids enjoy this game. However, this may be the last time I purchase a game through Steam considering that LAN play is disabled unless each child has their own Steam account. I could give my Steam password to friends across the country, and they could all play my games with little problem. In my own home though, they can't play each other because the gaming industry is so concerned about making a profit. I try not to spoil my children. The are awarded with good behavior and hard work with an allowance. My oldest worked hard to save up his allowance, birthday, and Christmas money to build his first gaming machine (so he could play multiplayer with his little brother). The fact that we would have to buy new copies of all their games is ridiculous. From here forward, I will not be purchasing any games intended for LAN play, unless they will play simultaneously under one account in the same home.

This game still sucks ass. The rubber banding seems to be solved, and there were more reseources around the place, but the heat kills relentlessly (and it's summer just about every-damned-where), monsters swarm the spawn, and the permanent loss of max hp every time you die is just idiotic.
As of currently there is no way to register to play online making the entire point of this mod void. DO NOT BUY. Why do you even have to register if it's a steam game?

I really feel like this game has more praise than it deserves.   This is one of those games that I absolutely adore until about the 4th round.  It has so many things I love, and so many things that make it fun - and then all the sudden it goes really bad. You spend so much time grinding and grinding only to have it all destroyed almost instantly with barely a chance to make it through. The main problem is though, that after you lose everything - the game continues to get harder.   Now there is no doubt I'm certainly not the best at this game, but I'm also no where near the worst. Even with 5 people playing with me, we can't manage to survive very long once the massive mobs start coming.   I want it to be hard to an extent, to where I can actually win it.   I think that it's a great game damanged by the inability for casual players.

This game is terrible, I actually can't believe people actually like this. Why do you have to click every single time to chop down a tree or mine a rock? Don't even get me started on the desync. I wish I never sent money on this game, its is the least worthwhile POS I have ever played. And I've played some bad games.

***Updated review***  This game is for serious, experienced gamers only. It is not casual and it is not pleasant to play by yourself. God have mercy on your soul if you join a server during nighttime...   -made a server with an experienced friend (his gift version included the original along with dlcs which is better than this purchase i refunded). Downloaded a ton of mods and dumbed down a lot of settings. Games pretty fun, especially the community made characters, but still insanely challenging. Vanilla is absolutely NOT casual. I'm sticking with my original opinion that this game isn't meant for casual players. It's serious and merciless. Its really necessary to read guides for this game. Nothing is explained and everything is learned painfully. So avoid any server that's not in endless mode. I wish they have some sort of quick guide for new players. It's definitely designed for a specific player base. I will be playing it more for sure.

Whats the point of this game? Its no more a survival game than a grapefruit is a sports car. I bought this to play with a bunch of friends, but after hours of playing haven't experienced any enjoyment in the slightest. Traditionally survival games have you build up to a point, but after two evenings of playing with 5 people we have no shelter, no armor, no weapons, nothing. We barely are able to build a science machine before some hostile creature comes and ruins everything. Trying to collect resources is like pulling teeth. You step 100 feet away from your spawn and you get chased down by a pack of 6 hounds, each with 150 health, while you get a measly amount of health and are lucky to do 20 damage on a hit, meanwhile the hounds can kill you in 1-3 hits. And each time you die your max health gets lowered until you can get one hit by a bumblebee. Progression is basically impossible as enemies are vastly more powerful than the player, and theres no progression of difficulty.  Im all for a challanging survival game, but when its so horribly lopsided against the player it loses all enjoyment.

Tedious game with a beautiful make-up. Don’t Starve is one of the more popular indie games of the recent years for reasons I simply do not understand. It does look charming indeed. In fact, it has beautiful Tim Burtonesque style graphics and the game easily grabs the attention of anyone who takes a look at the screenshots. You start as a character whose only goal is to survive as long as possible. Similar to other survival games, you farm, craft, build to stay alive. The first problem with Don’t Starve is that the grinding part is simply boring. Often, it feels like a flash game with a fairly bad user interface where you click, click, click with your left mouse button without having any kind of fun. If you are curious about how grinding can be fun, please check Terraria out.   Second major problem with Don’t Starve is the permadeath. I am not suggesting that permadeath is bad per se, it can be quite enjoyable when it is done right. In Don’t Starve, however, it turns the tedious game design into something unbearable. You may find yourself grinding for hours, just to die by a random encounter (and it won’t be your fault). Oh yeah, some might suggest “that’s what the game is about” or “you will learn from your death”. Just give me a break… By now you should have played plenty of difficult video games to differentiate good game design from bad ones. Just look at the Souls series. When you die, you know you made a mistake. Maybe you made your move too early. Maybe you did not block the attack when you were supposed to. And if you die, you may lose your “souls” and thereby some of your progress, but not the entire game. In Don’t Starve, unless you are playing with a second monitor with wiki open, there is no way of knowing what will kill you. The only way to learn about what kills you is to be killed by it. And then you will start over, go through the tedious grind for hours and die again for another reason you could simply not prevent. In Don’t Starve, you are Sisyphus…   Last but not the least, the combat is atrocious. Combat in Don’t Starve is literally the same combat in any of the other thousands of flash games. If you have a good armor, left click the enemy until it dies. Or alternatively, make the enemy chase you and do your attacks while you are on the run.   If dull, repetitive games with poorly executed game mechanics are for you, play Don’t Starve. If you have a friend who happens to have the same tastes as you do, play Don’t Starve Together. But if it is the art style that pulls you in, your valuable time would be much better spent rewatching The Nightmare Before Christmas.  [b]3.5/10[/b]

I like Don't Starve. I'm not sure how playing with online randos was supposed to enhance the experience, tho. In Don't Starve Together I spent 75% of the time dead, not knowing about the differences--or more often, because everything around the entrance was picked except seeds & flowers.  "Git gud" isn't helpful once you are already dead on the two "Newbie Friendly" servers with anyone playing. I will try private with friends sometime, but I see no reason to play with randoms. Community was as helpful and friendly as in LoL. I see DS as a roguelike, or like an old NES game: learn from your deaths. But for DST the best way to learn is to research? No thanks. I buy games for fun and discovery, not so I can rote memorize what others figured out.  Don't get me wrong, I'm not faulting the difficulty. Difficult is great when one can insert another quarter and start over. But, if you die in DST you just sit there, not playing the game until others find time for you. People you've just met who are already annoyed that they are getting brain drained have to come rescue you.  My final complaint is that the loading screens are too way too long. Even just the list of servers takes over two minutes to come up. In DS loading took a bit (meaning I know this laptop is an underperformer), but nothing like in DST.   If I could go back I would have bought Oxygen Not Included on sale instead of the DS bundle. O2NI is in early access and it's massively fun! But, after this I'm concerned Klei'll slap an online mode in as an afterthought.

Having played only ten minutes of Ricochet I can assure, without a microgram of uncertainty, to anyone of any background, that the interactive experience known as "Ricochet" is the cornerstone of Human achievement in the arts--nay--the peak of man's consummation itself! I see myself to be perpetually indebted to whatever deity unfurled the momentary lapse and position in which not only is this masterwork accessible, but also that I dwell in the juncture of living among the virtuosos who gave birth to the interactive marvel. How might a single mind solicit to inspect such a transcendent monument? Be forewarned, dear reader, that I, nor any man, could possibly hope to dissect a work of this calibur by his lonesome. Hell, I refuse to consider that an array of one thousand strong could decipher it! However, similar the prodigies that created it, I can only hope to muster the copious amounts of genius pouring from this work and cram it into the confines of the english language.  Upon initiating "Ricochet", you are greeted with so much symbolism to consume that most average citizens of our realm would choose to exit such a dense and meaningful screen. It is too much to the man with an anemic consciousness. I hardly know where to start when considering bringing this knowledge to the common people. I shall begin with how the work addresses the aboriginal of life and nature itself--birth. The anterior screen showcases many images, one of which tends to dominate the human's attention, as it is the most leviathan icon currently viewable. The gargantuan circle adorned by futuristic glows and structures is a symbol for the birth of the individual, as well as the birth of man into the technological age. Allow me to elaborate. The neo-digital ring depicted is an obvious allusion to the birth canal that nature devised each human to pass through. "Ricochet" proves this by how close up to the circular (or rather, somewhat polygonal) shape the art goer is. The moment is almost demonstrated as if your head is about to pass through, yet you are not quite out yet. You, dear reader, may be asking "Well, if it were the birth canal depicted, why isn't there a light on the other end? Isn't that usually how the birthing process is shown?" Well dear reader, you are absolutely right! Keen observation of yours, if I do say so myself! However, this is clearly intentional coinciding the entirety of "Ricochet"'s premise. You see, "Ricochet" proposes that in a rapidly advancing digital age, you are born into as much shadow as you were conceived in originally, hence the futuristic design of the configuration. Whether or not the craftsmen of this piece intended to imply that we are merely headed in that direction or we have already lived this concept is entirely disputable. There is much, much more to discuss about this object, but for now the picture requires more context, so I shall leave it at that. Moving on to the next point of interest, another image stands out. Yes, the icon associated with the game's title (to be discussed later)--the feature's logo. On first observation, one may assume the logo is but a relapse of something straight out of a 1980's film--font and all. Be that as it may, the visual holds a profound connotation. When the logo is rotated 180 degrees, the image appears to imitate the lower section of a triangle! Of course! Now, as you would assume from such a work, this holds a variety of nuance. However, I will discuss my interpretation of the logo's meaning. You see, the bottom of a triangle can be associated with the masses. The largest in number, yet trampled upon by its aristocratic counterparts. A classic case of the proletariats versus the bourgeoisie. The logo attaches itself with the work--"Ricochet". Clearly, the masterpiece's author's intended to represent the common man. Not only that, but the logo suggests something more, as it is rotated so the bottom of the triangle is at the top, The rotation confronts the idea that this piece will give the proletariats the power to overthrow the few that control them and restore power back to mankind itself. While this has not happened, I presume that the craftsmen who administered "Ricochet" assumed that would happen. That is one of the major reasons for the game's futuristic settings, after all. "Ricochet" shall not bring light to the people until technology and the people have collided with one another, allowing the work's true power to disseminate. Such tenacity bequeaths my soul optimism for our posterity. What beauty to behold, the day "Ricochet" provides its rightful nectar to the dry third eyes of the public! Excuse me, I got a tad passionate there. Yet, the principal still stands. I digress, there is more to discuss, and so little allotment for one lifetime! The next immensely abstract element of "Ricochet"'s title card are its four options. Of course, an important element to any interactive piece: choice. "Ricochet" insinuates that any choice you make can be boiled down into four simple decisions: "Find, Create, Options, and Quit". Allow me to elaborate on each of those phrases. Find--discovery, you choose to make a journey of some kind to quench your nature-given curiosity. You may not only find what is on the outside, but also evaluate what is on the inside. Create--to craft, to make something of your own. To use your abilities to craft your own solution to any problem. To create is to show yourself to others, much like the artists of "Ricochet". Options--to alter or change how you will solve a problem. You may not solve the solution in the most efficient way, but by changing how you operate, you can avoid any negative feedback one may receive. And finally, quit--to cease, to make null any progress of your heart and mind. To stop evil, or to stifle good. The most threatening and harsh choice of them all. Each of these choices can be intertwined with one another, yet they each build a unique experience. Moving along with my simple observations, the first two options specifically state the word "Server", along with "Find" and "Create". It's my humble opinion that the word "Server" serves as an opportunity for the creators to manifest a dissection of religions and their deities and how they are found by many people, and how each and every one of them was also created by many people. A "server" is someone who, well, serves another man. Many look to gods as mere reflections of mankind, showing them as forgiving or blessing, rather than a lonesome creator of all. The authors of "Ricochet" point out the obvious irony that humankind tends to worship themselves when establishing religions based around gods. These deities, while on a surface level they are higher than humans, are merely there to serve as a torch to show man its way. "Ricochet" shows these two options alongside one another to demonstrate how comedic and silly the concept of religion seems to be. While you may not personally agree with those statements (and I may not as well), it is the view of mankind that the work builds. True or not, the work still stands. While there are many more avenues of the starting screen, one man cannot possibly see them all. I, for one, cannot hope to understand every concept displayed. Therefore, I must continue my analysis.  Without getting into the still immensely compact consequences for selecting one of the phrases, the systems of "Ricochet" hold a host of implications. First off, you, the player, control a clearly hominoid individual. You represent a member of the public. A representation of the base of the triangle of class, as discussed earlier. In this future, you are pitted against another bipedal combatant, to serve as entertainment for the bourgeoisie. There is no other explanation of the ridiculous colours you are adorned with. It's an allegory for a sport, two opposite teams compete against each other to entertain--  Wait, I'm running out of space! I'm afraid that's all I can say... don't be fooled, I-

Love the original game but the Forge is another beast entirely. It takes quite a while just to find a group to get started for some reason, many people are bouncing from lobby to lobby and the quickmatch system elimatinates the chance of looking for specific players/levels. It also appears to have a much more toxic and low effort community than what you typically find in DST since the Forge is a much more forgiving/shorter game mode.   On the subject of low effort, the encounter itself isn't particularly difficult but most groups don't even get close. It looks like most players have never played a multiplayer dungeon game before and don't care to understand or execute simple concepts/strats and would rather just mash the attack button and cry for heals.  I assume the idea was to warm up more of the casual playerbase to approach more difficult, fun and well-scripted boss content in the regular DST game. Unfortunately the execution appears to be just plain terrible in the way that lobbies are set up and players are distributed ie. the quick-match system. The weapon and armor skill kits also leave something to be desired.  These issues really need to be addressed asap since the way the Forge UI is now integrated with DST seems like there's something rotten in an otherwise beautiful product. I don't like games where the sole purpose is dying repeatedly and starting over, with no reward beyond 'now you don't die anymore'.  But even after you survive winters, get a crock pot or three, after a while, there's nothing to do.  It's an essentially pointless game with no real outlet to even be all that creative - what it does, there's other games that do better.  Survival crafting? Minecraft. Terraria. Starbound.  It's repetitive; the main reward for doing everything is the ability to do a new game + in somewhere that looks about the same.    The colors are bland and the general tone is bleak; for all their aping Tim Burton's style, they seem to forget that all of Burton's works at least try to have a soul. For a while, I could make it mildly entertaining by setting the world to ridiculous parameters and watching it massacre itself, but eh.

Game is not designed for Multiplayer. Anti griefing mechanisms are a complete joke, everyone can come in and wreck your public game. First time i have EVER seen a game's singleplayer and multiplayer being sold seperately. What a scam.  Next upcoming games: Don't Starve in style In this game you will finally able to explore the third part of the game, the options menu!   Seriously, it's just laughable what games have become...  Being sold in seperate parts, episodes and idiotic things like that... And i am not talking about FULL games, like Half Life, that is just called "episode", i mean games like ALL that telltale garbage, that is basically ALWAYS a SINGLE game, split into 5 billion mini games... Just release the full freaking game or expect me to get the game somewhere else when it's complete... I had to wait for the Strong Bad game forever. Not that i actually waited but come on... the Homestarrunner website was dead even before the last episode of the game came out... WHY would anyone do this? You have something that catches people's interrest, release 10% and then wait for people to lose interrest, to sell the rest of it... Not saying that this is what DST is exactly, but this is what "buying games" has become...  Am i the only person in the world that thinks, that when you buy something, you get that thing? When i order pants at amazon, they send me pants, and then take my money. When i "order" a game at steam, they instantly take my money, and almost never deliver the thing that i bought...  Really don't know what is worse here. The game, the fact that it's only half a game, or the fact that the developers are just constantly lying to their "fanbase" and scamming people into spending more money on the game, while at the same time not improoving anything...

Overwhelmingly positive ? This game is freaking unforgiving!  i tried to go in solo first, beside the ridiculously long learning curve the game is unforgiving as all hell EVERYTHING tries to kill you, hell even the food you pick from the ground tries to kill you if you dont consume it immediately (mandrake) Beside your character being hungry constantly and i do mean freaking constantly, im a guy who works in the woods and even i dont get this hungry after working for 6 hours straight So...you have to keep track of your sanity, hunger and health (which btw is a pain in the ass to gain back) unless if you wanna spend all day catching butterflies, all while farming resources and building stuff in your "base"  The game doesnt explain ANYTHING, youre thrown into that god forsaken world and die after you realize that that one lasagna you ate decreases your health and sanity i had to get certain mods to even remotely have a good experience  And beside ALL what i just said, the game has durability on LITERALLY EVERYTHING Your winter hat has durability and it just degrades for no fucking reason, hell even your fucking rock which is the only thing that allows you to move around in winter has durability... what the hell man! The combat is horrible but thats probably because the game is 2D and you can't really do much when it comes to that, youre sort of locked into using auto attack because otherwise youre at an even greater disadvantage And dont get me started on the bosses that come at the end of every season... All in all i dont like this game one bit, i guss im part of the minority but if you hate all the things i just listed above then you too probably wont like this game   But hey im probably gonna get stormed by fanboys now because of the overwhelmingly positive rating to their beloved game

New players ask for refunds, stay away untild devs sit down and actually try to test their game.

This very short review doesn't cover everything that is good and bad about this event.  Like with Don't Starve Together you have two options which will decide how this event will go for you:  1) Make friends/bring friends and play this event with them and you will have a challenging and fun experience with cool rewards.  2) Play with random people and experience the full brunt of why people ruin multiplayer games regardless of how good the base game is.  Conclusion: Klei leaves it to the players to create a player friendly environment where you can interact in a sufficient way (discord, teamspeak) and find friends (Klei forums, steam groups etc.).  But in this case where large coordination is of the utmost importance to beat the Forge mode, this self-service system backfires grossly and shows that Klei does not sufficiently supply their player base with the tools to prepare for such large scale events. Hence, why I will not continue to play this mode beyond my 2 hours or so on it because there is too much effort and stress for little to no reward.

TL:DR This game will kill you endlessly for your ignorance without ever explaining what went wrong or why. Don't play it.  Absolutely do not play this game, UNLESS you have played the normal Don't Starve. Why? Because this game expects you to be a master of the original (because adding this feature to the original game was just too hard and making money off people is great).  I'm known for enjoying a challenging game with friends. But this game is not a challenge, it's just a constant death sentence. Even after having learned as much as I could from wiki's and friends who love Don't Starve, I always found myself dying. It just isn't fun to die because you're ignorant of something that you can't possibly learn without cheating or using a wiki. Not saying I need my hand held, but just being told that this item is going to vanish from the face of the earth in the next few minutes would have been nice to know.  Those of you that enjoyed the original game, play this with random people on public servers or play with other friends that have beaten Don't Starve. Do -not- try to get friends that have never played the normal version to play this unless you plan to force feed them information for 12 solid hours. (That might not even be enough).   Pros It's popular enough to find plenty of random public servers. It's a lot like the original game (so I've been told). It seems simple. The game has an easy interface.  Cons Every character is either brokenly good or dies incredibly easy. (Yes, I did say everyone.) Rogue-like deaths with no rewards. (You die, game over, that's it.) (CORRECTION: You get vanity clothes... Woohoo?) No tutorial, guide, or in game help of any kind. (Get ready to read a lot of wiki's) Difficulty increases dramatically over time, making joining a server a day or more old completely pointless. (Instant death if joining in the summer or winter.) Perma deaths on servers. (Many public servers are forgotten because people spawn in a die on the spot.) (CORRECTION: You can roll back time one day, according to @Egg. Never seen this used though.) Even after tens of hours of gameplay, expect to keep dying after only a few hours in a new world. (Why are you still reading this? Just walk away from this game already)

First off, it'll say this review was posted in 2017. Well I've changed my mind at this point and time. Just... read if you want to find out the horrible truth.. This game. Oh boy. Don't Starve Together is an amazing game, with developers that care so much about the game that they don't patch bugs that have been in for 4 years and literally break the ga- heh, anyways, it's still a very enjoyable experience overall, but I had just experienced the most disturbing thing I'll possibly ever see. I absolutely cannot recommend this game just due to the chance that this might happen to anyone else.  Ok, so, there is a character in the game named Wigfrid who is a battle warrior and mostly has to hunt for food. So I was just hunting right, in the middle of a desert, just waiting for that delicious koalefant to soon be in my stomach. But, well, there is also a 5% chance something much more terrifying can spawn. And I was one unlucky warrior that night. The "Varg" (swedish for Wolf) is a massive Wolf that summons its other wolves to aid it in combat. It's truly an overwhelming enemy. Well, before I knew it, I was completely surrounded by hounds. But something was wrong.  The Varg deeply stared at me, and the hounds just kept barking. Usually after about 3 barks they attack. Well, all I had at the moment was like, some grass and twigs in my pocket and the Wigfrid character's battle spear and battle helmet. The hounds suddenly just darted in and carried everything I had away in their mouthes... keep in mind this whole time I was alone and in the middle of a desert. Well, within just a few more seconds, they tore off my skin "Shadow Armor". It's just a skin so not actual armor. Anyways, not much longer I was tackled by the mighty Varg itself. I knew I should have died at that moment. But life just kept going at me, huh?  You can probably imagine what happened right after that. So much was going on, I, I didn't know what to do. It was only about 30 seconds in that I had the entire scence scarred into my mind. Some time later my character just completely got knocked out, which I'm assuming was from deleriousness from the extreme pleasure. My character woke up the next morning with all the stuff I had next to me. Well, my hunger was full at least. I came back to the base very ashamed that day. Pretty much everyone laughed at me, some took screenshots. It was horrid, but nowhere near as horrid of what had happened yesterday. Sigh. Even Wigfrid was groggy, started looking like she was crying later.   Well, all in all, this game is what happens when developers make something good and decide to completely ruin it from just one thing. And yes, I know, you do not have to hunt in the game. But at one point in time, you'll go hungry and no one has food. It'll be your only chance really. And just the chance, that 5% chance of getting that image burned into your head. That's something scary.  If you do decide to get this game anyway, please. Just contradict the title. It's much better to embarrasingly starve than... I don't even want to remind myself of it anymore. Well, bye. Please, save yourselves from the Varg.
100% regret buying it, bad controls and tentacles spawn outside the swamp and randomly attack you. What a joke and a waste of money, what a great way to end a run.

Game doesn't work for ubuntu. Downloading from steam is bugged, nothing downloads into the game folders, it simply finishes the install instantly then claims to be finished. Trying to play the game results in an expected "Missing executable file" message. This is an error that has been happening for years with other games as I've seen people searching for solutions since around 2012. No solutions are ever offered; eventually someone fixes the bug on the dev side and it works for everyone.    Unfortunately my girlfriend and I just wasted $40 dollars on a beta so that we could play together only to find out we can play it one at time on our windows based PC. Don't risk your money if you're using ubuntu.
