Insanely hard. At least in Terraria you could kind of, set yourself up, lock yourself away for the night. This game will constantly kick you when you're down. Need to increase your sanity? Good luck doing that without starving to death. Finally got enough grass for a sleeping bag? It's one use, and now you don't have grass to make a fire. Just started raining? Good luck keeping your fire going while you're attacked by four bats.   Edit: I managed to enjoy this game a little more by adding mods.  Edit 2: I don't really like the combat, kiting is annoying. Edit 3: The visuals are cute and there is depth in the crafting system if you can tolerate the high learning curve to find it. I imagine the game was very different on launch. Addons have cluttered the menus and there are not enough in-game instructions for new players.

The whole game is just meh.  Farming crops/stones/ores/fruit = Holding down the mouse button. Normal pickaxe or golden doesn't seems to matter all that much. So I got a Mod to increase their durability as I doubt chopping down 5 trees would kill an axe.  Combat is the same. It's just a check on who has higher health, defense and attack speed. There is no skill involved in it. If it at least was a bit like Zelda A link to past it could have been far more fun. Build an iron armor or wood armor as quickly as possible btw. But the best way to combat spiders is just by using traps.  Various things are a bit unreasonable. Like food. Why do I need to eat 8-7 steaks to fill up my hunger to max? Do you really eat 7-8 steaks per day? You can eat so many roasted berries without getting full either. It's kinda ridiculous.  Why does the temperature gets to freezing during rain in spring when the normal temperature was 27 celcius? Also why can't I just build a shelter to stay under? Also why does it rain for what seems like 3-4 full days?  Why do I need to use poop for every plant I plant?    Overall it really isn't all that fun. I tried to enjoy it for the 9 hours I played but meh. Not worth it.

I should preface this by saying that my son in law is african american. We routinely play video games together as a sort of bonding experience. One in particular is the 2d powerhouse Terraria. I really wanted to enjoy Don't Starve. I had seen the Totalbiscuit review of this game ((that part where he hunts for manure LOL!!)), and thought the game had looked interesting at the time. However, I had clearly not had paid too decent attention to the review.. when we fired the game up, my laptop, his pc, we began chosing characters. To which poses the question.. Why are there no african american characters? Is it coicidental that the actual only "dark" character happens to be a monster, aka, the spider? It's 2017 now, and in this climate of change, you would think that the indie game scene would be the first to change. I've seen some games take charge in the war against racism and white privelege, but this is a survival game, which strives for REALISM. In an apocalyptic setting, there would be african americans. There would be latinos. There would be muslims, and anyone else.. Not just white people. I saw the available characters and I told him to shut it down. We decided to play l4d2 instead, a survival game with actual minds put behind it. Take some responsibility, you are the face of a generation. You can make the change, if you have an open mind, open heart, and bravery. It's a shame that so many these days do not though.

A good old survival game. This game has a different art-style and actual characters/personalities than the usual survival games. A lot more fun with friends. Each season is different from eachother, meaning different tempatures, different bosses, different enemies and mobs, depending on seasons. There are also caves and ruins that you can explore! And of course, they have lots of different treasures! You can also get in-game drops, which are purely cosmetic and do not give any benefit to the player other than cosmetic reasons. You do not have to spend a dime in game, you can just play normally and gain drops by playing! Which is an another plus. The only nitpick I can give is maybe the community, but it's here and there, it's mostly just russian trolls, which are to be expected from a popular survival game.  8/10 Very Good!

One of my favorite games. Strong mechanics especially survival ones in an industry studded with survival games where survival is more of an annoyance than a strength. Outside of that, the graphics are very stylised and fit the theme and feel of the game, and the devs have taken simple mechanics like kiting and cooking and made them into something really special that most games don't give you. At the time of this review I have 124 hours on the game and each one has been a blast. Honestly before I even go into detail, buy the game if you love not only the art style, but the survival genre in general. This game does have some flaws, such as the occasionally crash or connectivity issues, but for the most part, Klei have made an amazing thing with this. If you're a fan of the original Don't starve and it's gameplay, then you will feel right at home here. However, your home is no longer an issue.  Now your house is full of your friends and even some strangers, how'd they get here, allowing you and the others to either work together or against each other. For the most part the player base is very nice to each other. Of course some people won't be a saint, but very few people will be mad if you're a new player. While playing online, if someone joins my server that is new I teach them the basics and let them discover the game for themselves.  The items in the game are a nice addition of character cosmetics. Now this is not a perfect game and isn't for everyone, but if you are curious about this game, my advice is to try it. This game is something fun to do and meet people on. The survival is refined and keeps the player engaged and planning with its in game seasons. Overall, this game is definitely a 8.5-9/10. This game is the survival game to just hang out and relax on with your friends. The key is to never really worry about "playing the game wrong." Just have fun with exploring and trying everything this game offers.

As far as survival games go this is one of the better ones in my opinion. Unlike Minecraft this game's difficultly very much increases when night falls thus making defense preparation and strategy making a much higher priority. This coupled with the hunger and sanity levels being a core focus of the game and directly effecting gameplay makes it quite an enjoyable experience. I also found the Seasonal Changes to be quite an enjoyable element of the game limiting what resources are available and can be collected at any given time. In addition the multiplayer feature of the game is solid and with the game's lower system requirements it can be played on any modestly powerful IBM Compatible PC. So for those of you who want a fun strategy/survival game you can play with friends I'd say it's worth your time and money.

I got this game because I was trying to find something to play with my gf. She's not a gamer at all, so I needed a more simple game that would be fun for her while also being challenging for me, but that I wouldn't have to just carry her through it.  We just got it recently, but this game has been great for that. It's simple enough with the scavenge and build mechanic that it's pretty easy to understand. I take over more of the combat which can be difficult at times, especially when you both get swarmed. Overall, it's a great game to play together, especially since we're long distance. I'd definitely recommend it to anyone else trying to find something to get their girl into gaming.

[h2] How I played [/h2] I played ~20 hours of Don't Starve (singleplayer) and ~80 hours of Don't Starve Together in groups of 2-3 with about 5 friends.  I have not played the new "Return of Them" update though it looks to have expanded the end game. [h2] The First 20 Hours [/h2] Don't Starve Together begins at its best: as a treacherous adventure.  Building a routine, discovering the behavior of strange creatures, and responding to unseen events slowly increases your confidence that you can beat your previous record.  However, you will likely die due to a lack of preparation every new season.  I believe that this stage of the game holds up for both solo and group players. However, be careful how you build your group.   [b] An experienced player should not introduce a new player to this game [/b].  My attempts to have new friends join result in me warning them of the dangerous surprises that are supposed to be overcome.  It is obviously much more fun mismanaging your base and starving together than having someone tell you how to play. [h2] 20 - 60 Hours [/h2] During this stage, it was important to me that I played with a group.  Routine days, where you could just chat with friends, are punctuated by engaging encounters.  At this stage, the nuances Klei have filled their world up with begin to surface.  Some of these details can be utilized to expand your base and some just make the world feel richer. [h2] 60 Hours & On [/h2] This game has a lot of content and I already got a lot of hours.  However, you know you're not going to die unless you start taking risks at this point.  If you're planning on dominating your world, then there is still a lot of content.  However, I was really only interested in overcoming the survival challenge. [h2] Conclusion [/h2] Don't Starve Together was one of the best games I've played.  I suggest you find at one person who has the same level of experience in the game as you and you'll get more than your money's worth.

This game is very challenging and requires you to learn how to play it to get past certain points, almost like learning a new skill. The art, both music and visual are pretty exceptionally well done and very unique to the game in particular. The developers are also very open about their userbase modding the game so when you go through the workshop you can completely personalize your entire Don't Starve experience. The only complaint I have about this game, (and it's pretty major) is that this game has no idea how to reward you and doesn't know how to keep challenging you once you've learned it. But, trust me, you will not figure this game out in a couple of days unless you've got a surplus of time.

Outside of my personal affinity with Webber, this is probably my favorite multiplayer game of all time, at least in terms of ones for just playing with a few other friends. Even with my multiple obsessive phases over this game, I still find new content almost every time I play it, either from updates or just me finding something for the first time even after over a hundred hours. The potential in this game is vast, from creative projects like base-building, genuinely stressful bosses, to just hours and hours of satisfying progression at a group. It's hard to ever get bored of the game, and the only reason I don't have infinitely more hours on it is I get butthurt sometimes after i mess up a long run.  PLAY IT

DST is one of my favorite survival games. It has a very lovably spooky-cute art style and sound design, a surprising amount of lore, the option to play solo, a whole cast of funky characters, and a whole lot more! It's one of the only games I'll willingly play single-player, and I love to play with friends and strangers alike! I've sunk a lot of hours into this game, and I feel like you might like to as well.  The game is mostly user-friendly and plenty of other players are open to helping out those who are lost! It provides a challenging survival experience without making it too hard to enjoy.   The modding community is very creative and have all sorts of fun little things to add to your game like original characters, new crafting recipes, and anything you could think of to tailor the game to your needs!

A Tim Burton-esque type game that I particularly enjoy and spend hours playing with friends some days when they want to. It was not a thing originally where a person would just play to earn items, but logging in to receive a daily item is exciting. The fact that Klei is still willing to update the game and provide us with new characters for the game with new skins is also exciting. I own all the recent DLC characters with a majority of their skins which I find aesthetically pleasant to my eyes.

Ooooohhh this is good! I love the way the characters and entities move with the land and sea. The game isn't 2D or 3D, but rather it is somewhere in the middle of the two, which makes DST stand out as unique. Another great aspect is that certain characters have starting items as well as sets of strengths and weaknesses that give them a leg up on other characters. The caves are a mysterious aspect to the game, and when exploring them, there is no telling what could happen. Lastly, the seasons and seasonal events, monsters and animals are a huge plus. There is so much else to say, and these are only a few great aspects. If I were you, I would definitely give this game try!

It's hard to believe a game like Don't Starve Together exists in a modern gaming industry plagued with companies who are more passionate about leeching as much money as it can from its player base using scummy tactics than making an actually GOOD game. Klei is one of my favorite developers of all time solely because of how pro-consumer they are.  Micro-transactions are purely cosmetic and free players get multiple opportunities to grab free skins for characters and items via daily drops, drops in game, and via twitch. So much new content with every update in the form of new characters, character reworks, expansions, new skins, and more. The developers really listen to community feedback and the player base for the most part is generally pleasant. As for the game itself:  IF you like survival games and appreciate the charming hand drawn style of Don't Starve, you should definitely pick this up either at full price or when it goes on sale (It's a steal either way as you get TWO copies of the game, one for you and to give to a friend, at least at the time of writing this review). I will not lie, it will be a bit tough starting out when everything is new and wants to kill you. Playing with other people, trial and error, and learning as I go has helped me survive for much longer. Don't be afraid to read stuff up online. You also have the option to play by yourself if you prefer it that way.   In short:  [b]Get this game. You'll definitely get your money's worth.

Probably the most easily fixable but completely broken and unplayable pub game I have ever played, GREAT with friends, but I am talking about the public servers here. All manner of griefer creative and uncreative plague the public servers, they do all manner of things stupid to ruin the experience and are like a cancerous plague on the game. The problem is this happens with any online survival game where douchery is possible and completely un-policed and it is up to the creator of the game to do something about it. Klei does absolutely nothing.  There is no report feature to send reports of players to get them banned from the actual game (so at least they would have to buy another copy), instead it is up to people to have to CONSTANTLY kick and rollback servers, and that only deals with the blatant and stupid griefing (willow base igniters), the smart ones will show up in waves to servers that have managed to get decent amount of days in and show up wasting your resources, eating all your shit, and taking all manner of things from your chests then logging off 2-3 days later. This "noob" behavior is not something you can easily call griefing but it is and most of them know what they are doing, but it could easily be controlled with minimal effort by Klei.  It is very easily preventable. Where is the report feature? Where is the Klei policing of this game, YOU DECIDED TO MAKE IT A PUBLIC ONLINE GAME! IT IS YOUR RESPONSIBILITY TO POLICE THIS. Sure playing with friends is great, but that is not the only part of the game.  My main issue isn't even actually the report function it is simple basic anti-douche functions like: 1. Disallowing players from hammering or setting fire to buildings they did not create, unless they have been in the server for 10-15 dst days. EASY FIX. 2. Disallowing players from accessing chests they did not create unless they have been in the server for 10-15 dst days. EASY FIX 3. Disallowing players from accessing fridges they did not create unless they have been in the server for 10-15 dst days. EASY FIX 4. Disallowing players from picking up crops planted by other players unless they have been in the server for 10-15 days. EASY FIX  There are some examples.  Increase cosmetic rewards significantly for people who play for good periods during winter, spring, and summer. Massively decrease the gifts cosmetic rewards for people playing during autumn (or even disable it during this time). This will stop the roaming bands of absolute degenerate dick faces who constantly fill autumn server after autumn server after autumn server take all the resources and then log off 2-3 days into winter. This happens CONSTANTLY, it is EXTREMELY RIDICULOUS DIFFICULT to get a good game going that progresses through winter spring and summer, and when you do the griefers love to show up and use all manner of shittery to screw it up.  These are all really simple and basic fixes, and together would eliminate about 90%+ of the griefing and in general shitty behavior in the game, but my issue is Klei doesn't do a fucking thing.  I want to play the game, but without friends who play this type of game I am done with it.

I'm obsessed with this game. I bought it on 12/2/19, it's now 12/28/19 and I've played 308 hours on it. I'm new to Steam and while I've bought other games to play with my SO, I'd consider this the game that really got me invested and familiar with Steam.   I'm still trying to figure out what my preferred game attributes are, but wanted to find something that I would really love. I know the most time I spend in most of my games and the most fun that I have with them is in collecting and building things. When I searched "Collecting" in the steam store, "Don't Starve" was right on the first page and only a few dollars, so I figured I'd give it a try.   I was sucked in pretty hard pretty fast. My SO saw me playing it and immediately bought it. Then we found out there was a don't starve together and we have been plastered to our screens playing it together or playing our own figuring it out since.   The fandom site is forever open with at least 5 tabs on my second monitor.   This game has really opened up so much more for me than just the game. I had no idea how to host a game, I was intimidated by mods, I was at a total loss for navigating this whole site.  Well. Not anymore. I would recommend getting the game achievements mod since it gives you little goals instead of just wandering around, though I easily have 20 others running on this.   Despite how much time I've been on this, I still feel like I haven't done or explored even half of what this game has to offer. I've barely spent any time in the caves and have yet to find the ruins, I still haven't built all the machines and there is just so much to do and figure out. And I'm so excited about it.   Bigger picture about this game is if you're new to steam, PC gaming or gaming in general, this is your easy entry gateway drug. If you're trying to pull someone into gaming with you, but they're intimidated and don't want to throw down a ton of cash or deal with anything super complicated, get this game. If you want a fun game to play with friends, get this game. It's for everyone of every level. My SO has probably played more games than I've seen in my lifetime and they're just as hooked as I am.   I plan on discovering every detail of this game before giving it up, but I've already bought this company's whole collection for after that happens. Cannot recommend enough.

This is hands down the greatest game of all times--past, present, future. It is approachable for players of all skill levels, yet has a depth of complexity that can captivate and entertain even the most discerning gamers. I quickly invested in copies for each of my children to play and rented a server, such was my level of captivation with the game. Every time a group of gamers logs on together, magic happens. Perhaps 'good natured, fun people' are drawn to the game; perhaps the aura of the game engenders good nature and fun loving. Either way, I'm a certified devotee.

5 / 5 stars!  Don't Starve Together is the multiplayer version of Don't Starve. 'Nuff said.  Instead of trying to survive alone, you've got buddies to help you out... or, alternatively, even more people/things that are trying to kill you. All in all, I can't recommend this game series enough. The game's re-playabilty alone is worth the money you'll spend buying it. There are a 1001 different ways to do things in this game, not including all the environmental settings and mods you can play around with.   If you're a casual gamer like me, you'll like the ease of the game. There's no special combos that you need to smash when you're being attacked. It's one of the best survival games around.

Easily a game that defined the decade for me. I have so many memories tied to the old Chrome demo version and old lets plays on youtube from around 2013, and Don't Starve as a whole has managed to stay as one of my favourite games of all time. The mechanics are easy to learn, yet hard to master, and consistent updates (and character refreshes!) make it so the game never feels stale, despite you doing the same thing every time you play: surviving. Being able to play with friends has enhanced the experience greatly, and I remember being so hyped for DST when it was announced way back then. Other than some lag issues, it never disappointed.

This game's main premise is simplistic. All you have to do is stay alive! This task is much easier said than done though and you are going to be constantly dying.  Do you think you are good at survival games? Not this one, I can almost guarantee it. Basically everything around every single corner is out to get you (including your character's own mind). I have quite a bit of hours under my belt, and I can safely say that I absolutely love this game. It is beautifully infuriating and will keep you coming back for redemption time and time again.

Don't Starve Together is what I would call a great game. It's a beautiful addition to the original Don't Starve, with plenty of it's own content (DLCs, mods, and otherwise). It's very fun to play with friends, and if you don't have any friends you can join a random server! I would recommend checking it out if you enjoyed Don't Starve.

This game is very simple on the surface. Don't fucking starve, its in the title you dolt. Unfortunately not starving gets boring eventually. Good news friend, there is much more to do in this game than just not starving. Going in with no knowledge you will likely die horrible death after horrible death. This is a great learning experience, and makes your overall transformation into a wizened, self-sustained, god king all the more satisfying. That's when you head down to the caves or fight a boss you thought you were ready for. You were not ready. This is the point when you will realize that after over 200 hours combined between this game and base don't starve and expansions, you barely scratched the surface of the game. And thus begins the process of getting the shit kicked out of you all over again and having to run home a defeated and with your ham bat shoved neatly up your rump. Great game 10/10.

Don't Starve is one of my favourite games of all time. It scratches every itch in terms of open world base building, beautiful Tim Burton art style and unique characters each with their own skill set. The DLCs each offer exciting expansions to the main game and are absolutely worth purchasing and provide hours of fun. I've played over 100 hours of this game, many more if you include the expansions and original Don't Starve, and will forever play more, you never run out of content and Klei just keep adding more.  Don't judge it wrong, It isn't as easy as it may appear, and some areas of the game (e.g. the ruins, Dragonfly and very long term survival) provide a high skill ceiling, especially if you go it alone, and will take some time to be able to reach.   My biggest issue with the game is the length of time new content updates take and they are often delayed for months at a time. However, the developers make sure anything they put to the live servers is fully tested and of the highest quality so they should be commended for that, despite it being frustrating.   Another small problem is older servers can become laggy.   This game enables a MASSIVE range of mods which greatly improve or change the gameplay. You can get them on the Steam Workshop for free.   If you've gone as far as to click this game, stop wasting time on reviews and just purchase it. You won't regret it.

TL:DR: The tagline is a good description.  Well-developed, unique, fascinating, and highly replayable.  Highly recommend.  There are few games as unique in feel as this one.  I love games where the learning curve kills you about 100 times before it shallows.  It's really a challenge to even figure out what you're looking at.  The game mechanics take a while to learn if you jump in with no reading about the game, but that's the fun part to a large degree.  Great characters each with fatal flaws to overcome.  Great balancing, with many different survival strategies.  One of the best features of this game is a development team that's really on the ball.  The updates come from servers that send you the updates quickly.  The updates are usually small and minor because of how well built the game is.  The devs listen to the community and it has great support.  This situation will never happen with Don't Starve: Me: "Okay, what to play?  I think I'll play some Ark tonight!" Ark: *klaxXxon* "2GB update-that-basically-does-nothing-and-certainly-doesn't-fix-any-bugs-and-downloads-at-the-speed-of-molasses required!" Me: "Well, ****.  I guess I'll download it overnight...I guess I could play something else..." Also me in the morning: "Well, ****. the updates still not done.  Their servers suck..."

I don't know why it has taken me so long to write a review for this game, but Klei is an absolutely outstanding developer. Time and time again they deliver on promises and make absolutely addictive and unique experiences. I would argue that DST is one of their greatest achievements. This is a game that keeps on giving, and they continue to support it and make new content and events. In my opinion, Klei is a model game developer. If you enjoy survival games you will love this game. The world and characters are charming and engaging. The atmosphere just works. If you play it you'll understand. This is obviously best enjoyed with friends. Just don't get to tilted when someone eats all the food and you guys starve during the winter.

This game is just fantastic all around:  -Beautiful unique art style -A large pool of characters for different play styles (and each have their own interesting personalities) -So many world customization options for adjusted difficulty (or just some fun chaos) -Fun for co-op or just single player -Character/item skins can be bought, but can also be drops for just playing the game (it's definitely worth supporting though) -Devs that seriously put so much love and effort into this game that they're still pumping out new FREE content consistently, especially with holiday events -So much more  It's given me so many good times both alone and with friends, and there's always new stuff around the corner. I promise this game is worth checking out and supporting.

This is a problem for beginners and has potentially led to many just checking out.

This game is a great example of an open world sandbox survival action-adventure ish game. This game allows you to do whatever the fuck you want while also being very uncompromising if you're incompetent . Playing with other friends make this experience way more enjoyable and replayable, while playing along is bearable, it is much harder to survive this way if you are inexperienced so grab some friends and bear the inevitable. The art style this game uses is truly unique. Never in a game have I been so captivated by all the characters, animals, and even items. To second that, the soundtrack in this game is amazing, the music is crazy catchy and will get stuck in your head, each song that places for certain actions you take are very memorable, probably because they play over and over again but regardless, this unique style of music is done to perfection. The amount of knowledge you need for the game is endless, setting up each season to be able to survive it is enjoyable for the most part while taking down bosses might be tedious, you can find many ways to kill them differently, some more effective than others of course. All in all, a great game for people who are willing to learn through the hardships of failing to survive from all the elements of this game.

This game is Absolutely gorgeous. Amazing Music, Wacky Characters. A lot of people say "It's like Tim Burton made minecraft" And I wholehearted disagree with that. It's an understatement. A good game that recently has been bringing new content.   Although sometimes being a letdown like the Forge for example. I like the battle arena and I guess I understand why it's not always there. But I expected it to be an introduction to a new area in the game. Where they are coming to invade from a portal and if left alone they would expand to make a base on this side of the portal while creating a new biome through the portal they came from. The base would occasionally send search parties to explore and if they find they could also send some attack parties like the dog waves. Also expected those new mini bosses, that could be soloed.  Also experiencing problems during combat that could use some hotfixes for example: - Charlie hitting me instantly once it becomes night. As you know it should be a while before Charlie appears when losing light and even then there's a few warnings letting you know to find light before she hits you. That didn't happen a few times and she ended up hitting me soon as it got dark.  - Inconsistency with tentacles popping out to attack you when it should always be the same amount of time. Where there's a few seconds when near a tentacle that it would come out to attack you when you're near. Sometimes it's random like coming out as you got close as if you were close the whole time thus attacking you. Or you confirmed a spot is safe because no tentacles popped out for at least a minute, at night, then it pops out. Might be related to the issue with bats and bees where they fly around and glitch the tentacle into staying asleep.  - Just recently a Terrorbeak hit and killed me even though I perfectly kited him = basically still hit me even though I dodged and was out of range. There was also an instance where a Terrorbeak kept reappearing on top of me constantly and after the 5th hit? it would ignore dissipating and just attack me. And as you know hitting shadows should always make them dissipate, a simple fix would be not to let them reappear within a certain distance from the character.  Edit- just found out it it has more to do with time where depending how much time has passed. When you kite moving away from mob and going back in the amount of time it takes to go back to hit depends if you're going to get hit or not. For example, you're able to hit werepig 3 times and safely back off if you're fast enough. Messing it up by being slower will let werepig hit but the issue is ping so safer just to attack twice.  Edit- ping, I like to use force attack and have it modded to not attack friendly things. However there's a ping issue where there's a delay for the character to carry out the action I made it do, however short, it's not instant. Because of that it totally effects the kiting in this game making it somewhat unplayable.  Edit- Mobs pushing each other is stupid, where you have multiple mobs aggro on you. When they attack they would usually miss since you're running without stopping but because the other mobs behind push it, it's range magically extends hitting you. Fix by causing them to be unmovable once attacking.  - Also dogs, and this is more of a nuisance of wasting time, where you don't know how many barks they would do sometimes it's once maybe it's twice or it could be that rare 4 or 5 times. It's a waste of time since you're there thinking how many barks will he do? should I attack him? just always bark twice  - Another problem is how far some mobs will chase you, like I was once stalked by a tallbird for like 2-3 biomes away, sure I stole it's egg but cmon f*** OFF Felicia. How you expect me to lose aggro when they're faster and always catch up & re-aggroing.  Edit - Then there's the bees... hassle and a pain to clear them off whether kiting or tanking. They all swarm to attack you once in range, and the bug of pushing each other is present. On the one hand kiting is time consuming and they the respawns are too short so it'll take a while to clear one hive. Tanking wastes of resources on making armor just to get honey, make bee box,etc.Instead they could make them swarm around the player like bats and attack in waves. Let's say there's 6 then 3 groups of 2s take turns attacking. When the first group of 2 attack whether hit or miss as they're going out the second group goes in to attack and it keeps going like that. Also the bees respawn should take longer or even easier starts after the last bee was killed.Then it goes back to regular spawn where the first killed spawns first,etc.. There's also a bug where killer bees don't count out even when attacking their bees within hive range, soon as i attack hive 2 come out. It happened back to back on 2 killer bee hives and on the second i died. wasted 2+ days and 2 full pig helmets just to get 5 honeycomb and the 6th killed me.  Seriously I don't know why they have kiting combat since there's tons of problems with it.

Baseline: A charming, quirky, yet satisfying game of strategy, survival, resource management, and mindless nonsense, with a bit of a learning curve. An excellent option for both solo play, co-op, or PvP. Tons of replay value plus regular reworks, updates, and new content added.  44 hours at time of review  Originally did not particularly enjoy this title, especially due to the learning curve but after forcing myself to learn the mechanics, crafting, tips, tricks, characters, and general experience, it's very much is an enjoyable game. Recommend using the Wiki or guides and starting with the standard experience. Also would recommend some mods that improve the UI and some information given in the game. Although this is the multiplayer version of the base game (Don't Starve), it can still be played as a single-player game. The art style is fantastic. The characters are quirky and fun, both playable and NPCs. Really no complains yet.

I have now reached my 100th hour through my journey of DST, and man. It's the best game I've played in ages, and the best $19 dollars I've spent in years. Either take on this harsh world known to us as The Constant by yourself, or continue on through your adventures with the aid and support of allies. Figure out certain character match ups and synergies to get the most out of your partner, or just hop in blind as someone you like the look of and check out where the wind ( Or the sea ) takes you. There is really no limit to how you survive, the habits you go about each day, or the way you make your base, or, really anything! If you're struggling, try out Endless mode for less stress when dying. If you're like me, you'll just whip up the wiki every time you get curious about how something works, or you may be willing to find it out yourself, or even make guides for others on the internet.  Whatever you choose your playstyle to be, make sure to have fun. That's why we play games in the first place, is it not? Anyway, It's getting late at night, and I'm running out of words to say, considering there might be a maximum character limit or something. So, Just remember, Don't Starve!

Don't Starve Together is the best way to play Don't Starve. Get a few friends together, find a nice place to set up camp and see how long you can survive against the terrors of this strange, fantastical land you find yourselves in.   With simple controls, fantastic, astonishing artwork, beautiful music and really positive, interactive community - truly a unique game. It has a lot to offer, with many hidden gems to discover. Developer build something so simple and nonetheless addictive despite it being a game without a particular goal.  The game has a long learning curve and it's really unforgiving to new players, it doesn't have a tutorial and makes you figure things out for yourself so you will need to spend some time researching how to play. You will be thrown into a harsh and unpredictable environment, every decision you make will directly impact whether u survive another day or die. Your abilities will constantly be tested so you will have to adapt to the current situation and prepare for the hard seasons. You will also have to learn from past mistakes and come up with a better solution that best fits your character and playstyle. You have to cater to sanity, hunger, and health, by collecting and crafting items from around the map which changes with each new world made, allowing for the player to explore new areas, or make different strategies based on their environment. Keeping the nightmares at bay with all the cool stuff you learned to craft. There’s a massive fun factor in discovering new ways to survive in the creepy little land of Don’t Starve.  The amount of options when creating a server is stunningly detailed and easy to navigate. You can choose all sorts of thing, from how many animals there are, how much food there is, how long the day/night is...   Downloading mods is highly recommended since mods are one of the best parts of the game. There are numerous characters to download on the steam workshop and other really fun and useful mods which can benefit you survive. I'm excited to see what else the mod community creates in the near future.   I’d recommend this game to anyone who enjoys a unique and challenging gaming experience, particularly if they have a few friends who are interested in the same thing
I enjoy playing with my friends and seeing what kind of chaos we can get ourselves into.

This is one of me and my girlfriends favorite games to play together. Most play sessions go for more than 3 hours! It's really hard to stop playing once you get started, because you get so sucked into the world.   Most of our play through's have ended with valuable lessons being learned, meaning we had to restart. If you aren't into survival games, where restarting is a regular thing, this may not be the game for you. We're barely getting to the point of crafting all of the games items and we're almost at 170 hours of played!  For me, the art style, at first, was questionable, but once you get into the game and see the world, it really comes together and you learn to love it.   The game play is amazing and extremely fluid. We haven't ran into any bugs and/or any real issues with the game.  Klei seems like a great company and is always releasing new content to explore. The mod support for this game is outstanding - We use many mods and would never go back!  This whole game has just been an extremely pleasant experience. Check it out for yourself!

Don't Starve Together is the multiplayer version of Don't Starve with new content. It is a high quality game with a unique visual style and interesting game play with a high difficulty. While it does have content that is not in Don't Starve in is missing a lot of content from non-Rain of Giants expansions. So in general if you want multiplayer get Together, if not get the original with the DLC which when on sale costs less than together.

This game is hard and frustrating at times - but it is so much fun to fail again and again in so many different ways that you have to try again and again.  Ok, here is a few more information: Surviving your first autumn is the first challenge that takes a lot of learning by dying. Once you actually manage that, you recognize that to survive winter you must get even better in fall and build a stash, preserve food, build better barricades, make more efficient recipes, etc.  When you finally got over winter... after many attempts, you think spring will be a charm, because finally, food can be gathered again! This is when the first actual boss showed up.  The different characters feel very unique, and require different tactics to play with.  Will gladly die aggain, 10/10 stars.

Can highly recommend this game, I played Don't Starve single player since it's alpha release can't say i've bought most of the single player DLCs but Don't Starve Together gives you the chance to enjoy the DLC features without spending as much money. This game can be enjoyed single player or in a group both feel great, single player "can" be overwhelming for new players as the boss health scales differently on DST but very fun if you know what your doing. I will say i was given DST for free because i owned DS single player since alpha, How ever i do still recommend it for it's price DLC characters don't feel too overpowered and it's just as easy/challenging with a DLC character vs with a non DLC character.  One of the strong points of DST vs DS is that there are different/newer characters to add spice to your game play. I do own all the "DLC" characters all of which are enjoyable in their own right. DST is seemingly constantly being updated which is very nice as well.  Mod support is pretty strong within this community most of which can easily be installed via steam and activated in game. Mods range from characters to mobs to even weather and effects, most of which are easy to install.  All and all i'd say 8/10 it's a fun game if you like these types of games, the art style is great the music is great. But after playing it over and over again it can get a bit boring but that's the same for any game. Also fuck the deer clops.

Don't Starve Together has became one of my favorite games over the years. I've been playing it for a couple of years and I still enjoy playing it. Playing it with a few friends is even more fun. You fight, survive and overcome difficult situations together. The survival aspect of the game may be a little frustrating at the beginning. You would find yourself dying a lot for the most of the time. I know how annoying that really is, I've been there before. The game is really tough in the beginning. Every time you approach to something new, you will get slapped by the game very hard. The main purpose of the game is trying to survive as long as you can. The game will try to kill you no matter what, keep that in mind. Patience is the key. When you start learning the major aspects of the game and get more experienced, the game becomes much more enjoyable. You will gain more and more information about all the little details and expand your knowledge to a greater level. After playing for a while you will realise that you overcome the toughest situations a lot easier than before. That is the reason why I love this game a lot. Its gameplay has this challenging gameplay that always keeps you thinking what to do next. The action never stops. You have to know what to do next, in order to survive.         The developers of this game still working hard. They update it frequently and add new features to the game.  Also there is all a lot of cool mods for this game in the steam workshop. The mod developers are also great. Their ideas and creativity is really amazing. You should check them out if you are interested in adding original and great features to the game.    I would say that this game has so much potential. And it still keeps growing. I would definitely recommend this game. It is a great game. Klei takes such a great care of their little baby. I hope they continue working on this game and don't ever lose their interest.

I love this game. It's a lot more complex than normal Don't Starve and a fun way to play with friends. A lot of my friends find Don't Starve too difficult but they'll play Together with me. You can customize the worlds to be as easy or hard as you want and even eliminating pet peeves altogether.

To start with I will give a little background. I got this game on the PS4 when it was free for PS+ members, so I have played much more than the Steam number shows. This is definitely my favourite indie game I have played.  Don't Starve is an incredibly good game, it has great depth and incredible replayability. There are many different characters you can unlock, each with unique traits that will make replaying this game continiously enjoyable. I would highly recommend buying this game, even if it is not on sale, although it does go on sale frequently.  The DLC Reign of Giants expands upon the world of Don't Starve by making the game even more challenging, by adding 2 more seasons, Spring and Autumn and reworking Summer to be much more difficult. It adds many new items that can change the way you survive. And with the new mechanic of smoldering items in Summer, the game gets a lot more difficult. I would also highly recommend purchasing this DLC because it adds an incredible amount of content to the game.

I wish they made Shipwrecked and Hamlet multiplayer too. I get it that singleplayer versions would become obsolete, but it's not about the games itself, it's about the fun players have and how much it would skyrocket if you could play with friends. Just my opinion, though.  DST is very unfriendly towards new players. A lot of information to process and pretty much every new thing you learn must be paid with a death. And without mods you basically must start anew every time.  Without its wikipedia one would need several months to learn what every character does and every single one's weaknesses. It really burns you out if you die at every blind step, to something the game doesn't even attempt explaining.  But fear not! Mods are here to help! There are a lot of mods that make the game very very very enjoyable! Especially with friends that is. It's a difficult game, but there is a lot of content and a lot of places to explore, build around, plan around and a lot of things you GOTTA RUN FROM AAAAAAHHHH.  With a bit of mod help you can turn deaths into simple consequences and not game overs. Play a run, with or without friends, with said failsafes. Explore first, challenge yourself later.  Its artstyle is very unique and simple. I can't get enough of it. The game is constantly updated and kept in shape. There is no reason not to give this game a try. At first there will be many inconveniences, but explore and also look up mods after a few playthroughs. Everyone has a rough beginning, a flaw I'd say, but as mentioned before, it is worth it.  Be persistent and don't forget to light up a bit during the night. Charlie will be onto you.

Not only is DST really fun but all the mods are really fun too. The base game is challenging and even once you understand how to take on all the mobs and survive, there's still a lot of fun in terms of customizing your base and crafting things.   Even looking at how your character interacts with things is really fun. I'd absolutely recommend to anyone who likes to play survival games - especially if they like multi-player survival games.  I also like that you don't have to pay for tons of stuff. Sure, buy some expansions, but you can gain new characters, outfits, emotes, etc. in-game, and there are also seasonal challenges that bring fun to the game.

While I am by no means "good" at this game, it is loads of fun to play with friends. It offers unique and difficult challenges and running around while screaming in panic with said friends is a blast.

Not every game that gets big content or seasonal updates also gets such colorful, character-filled, animated trailers for each update, which help the players understand what kind of world and character they are playing (immersion, role-play, gameplay, etc.). Keep in mind, animation is probably more work than simply recording and editing new gameplay footage. The devs care enough to tell a story with even seasonal events.  A strong and rarely seen indication of a Labor of Love.

Hi !  What much can I say except that I'm in love with this game ?  I'm really not the competitive type and consequently not really a big fan of most multiplayer situation.  Don't Starve Together is the best when it comes to play with your friends and try to resist and fight together against common foes and that is a really pleasant feeling for me.  Plus, from gameplay mechanics to music and art, everything in this game make the universe a cohersive whole with a nice Burton-esque feel. I mean, you can make flowers by planting butterfly, rabbit become evils bearded monsters when you're insane and some menacing tree with a screaming face is nicely named "Totally Normal Tree".  Finally, it's a pleasure to discover try after try what you can possibly do to improve this or that situation ... and there is a lot to try !  Anyway, thanks for reading this,  Have a nice day,  Leliot.

This game and I go way back, and I mean all the way back to the beginning when I pirated it just to have a chance to experience it. I bought it eventually of course, because this game is Klei's big baby boy prodigy, worthy of all the love and respect it deserves, and that includes the support I was more than willing to give. Is it hard to play? Yes. Do I cry every time my majestic base is destroyed by a moosegoose? Yes. But for every failure, I learn something new about the game, and it never ceases to amaze me how much I still have not yet uncovered. To this day there are still updates, events, and new content that keep things interesting, and it's genuinely my favourite game to teach new people. Klei, I love you guys. You have inspired me as an artist and I stole your background for a youtube video. Har Har. Peace out

This game just leaks charm out of every nook and cranny! It's a relatively complex game with easy to pick up basics, but it becomes harder to survive as time goes on, a feature i really enjoy wholeheartedly!  The art style is fantastic too! It reminds me of reading an old pop up story book you would find in your attic while doing spring cleaning. Every character has their own instrument for a voice and they somehow managed to make it fit every single character!  All in all, I wholeheartedly recommend this game, Don't forget, this game is Don't Starve TOGETHER. Give the extra copy you get to a friend and you will have hours on hours of enjoyment!

One of the most pleasant game experiences ever. It was decently hard at first but easily became one of my favorite games. It doesn't tell you that much off the bat so you're free to go as you please, which makes the experience ever more rewarding for finding things out. But, I think the main thing and the reason why it came out was due to the fact that you can play with other people. The experience with 2 or more people makes the game evermore fun and allows a multitude of possibilities and you all have to put your abilities to work.

I had high hopes for this game but was incredibly disappointed. There is no tutorial, so you have to learn how to play on the fly with no instruction. This might be fine if they had actually spent any time on something other than making the game kill you. You can't figure anything out without being attacked by bees or bats or having to eat constantly. Nothing seems to boost your health and just when you may have figured something out, congrats, you've gone crazy and monsters you can't fight now kill you. The combat system is useless, requiring you to SPAM-click and hope you hit something (you rarely do). I can't recall a less fun game I've played in ages.

Tip for playing on public server (aka, u don't kno anyone there)  1. Host your own server. Play until u can survive autumn into Winter at least.   2. Don't ask where base is. or if u do, don't be miffed if ppl ignore u. You are still a stranger. Its a rite of passage to prove you are competent enough at this game, to survive and explore for that period of time till u find the base. And also to protect the base from griefers and thieves.  On the same note, even if u find base, don't simply give out the location in chat. Unless u built the base from day 1.  3. Don't grief or steal. If you want anything just ask nicely. Food is free unless its scarce. Trust me ppl notice and they talk.

DS and DST are absolutely charming and creepy survival games. The art style and music are wonderfully atmospheric. Combat is quite simple but can prove rather challenging when coming up upon the later enemies in the games (especially in DST). If you love the survival rogue-lite genre do not miss either of these gems. On you lonesome or with friends the cast of zany characters and their special abilities will keep you crawling back for more. One last thing before you begin your adventures, be prepared to die... a lot.

I would recommend this to you if you like crafting, difficult/steep learning curve, lore, survival, skins, special events, cooking, farming, mods.  Game is best with other people. Singleplayer is optional but I would highly recommend getting "Don't Starve" for it's extra DLC . If you play on a random server you just gotta hope for the best and expect the worst because you could end up playing with novice/lone wolf players or great teammates. When you got good team synergy going you can take on the tough world and it's many beast, scoring quality loot to craft top tier gear. Beating any of the many bosses is always a satisfying feeling and can be easily done with some strategy and friends. Or you could get massacred and have a laugh. I would describe the combat as OG Zelda-esque that is heavily relying on the gear/items you craft to boost your stats {damage,armor). The combat is deeper than it seems at first glance. if you like shoot/blast/beat 'em ups you might not like this. Combat is much slower paced and takes strategy. There is elemental damage, magic, ranged, aoe, and even a couple of . If combat isnt your thing you could craft traps or recruit npc's to fight on your behalf or help your teammates by playing to the strengths of the variety of support class character(healer, cook, farmer, builder, etc).

Enormous amounts of content with devs still adding more (for free alongside paid cosmetics to keep the game profitable) and huge variety in how you can play based on where you make your base, how you build it, and who you play as. Workshop mods are pretty outstanding as well. If the premise of adventure-optional survival starting from scratch in a dangerous wilderness environment with tons of dynamic elements that take place which keep your surroundings always in flux sounds like fun, then the game has hundreds of hours of fun to offer you.  Anybody who loves to hunker down and be in it for the long haul with their survival game experience needs to at least try DST and let it hook them.

Oh. Don't Starve. This game has been a years long love/hate affair for me. Will this game frustrate you to no end and make you want to throw your computer against the wall? Absolutely. But you also won't be able to put the darn thing down until you finish it. This may take longer than expected. If you like survival games, sandbox games, atmospheric horror, this is for you. Other than a few minor persistent bugs, the gameplay is solid and enjoyable whether you are on PC, phone, or tablet. It is pretty consistent between devices.  I love the challenge of the game and the fact that you can scale the difficulty up or down in really dynamic ways depending on your skill level, whether you're playing with people new to survival games, or how silly you want it to be. The graphics are great, the customization of character and world is rewarding, and I feel like each gameplay experience offers me something new. I've been playing for years and am still discovering new, hilarious, and infuriating ways to die. For example, I was delighted to discover that you can damage a spider by lighting it on fire with an attack from a torch. I was not so pleased to find out that said spider will rampage all around the base and burn the whole thing to the ground. Back to the drawing board.  Seriously, give this game a try. There's something for everyone. Whether you like cute creatures, spooky atmosphere, designing houses, being a murder hobo and stabbing your friends in the back, or just need a semi-casual game to play on the John, this is worth the money. I think I got mine on sale but I honestly would have played $30 for it. You will get hundreds of hours of gameplay out of this (think Skyrim).

There are only three words: THIS. IS. AMAZING.  Don't Starve is a survival game where you... well, don't starve. You gather food, survive this world called the Constant, and - in Don't Starve - survive the trials of Adventure Mode. Don't Starve Together is the multiplayer version of Don't Starve, where you can play with others - collaborating, fighting, PVP, whatever! There are some subtle differences - Twiggy Trees, Forest Petrification, and plant disease. But no matter what mode you choose, make sure you stay out of the night - if you don't, the Shadow Queen, Charlie, will kill you in under a minute. And make sure to invite your friends to this game! They will love it.

After 100 entertaining hours on this game, here's my review. (Would have done it earlier but this masterpiece needs a good review).   11/10.  Don't starve together, has to be one of the best games i've actually ever played, like, you have the choice of going full solo, or no friends, or with friends, EITHER WAY, ITS FUN. The game comes with workshop mod support which leads to COUNTLESS content, even klei entertainment itself updates the game nonstop and that's just countless more and more content. Nothing is pay2win either, skins/rare skins can be earned through ACTUAL survival gameplay, and daily reward, also watching any dst twitch streams with your account linked gives you skins!  But why is this game so much fun? Well its because of variety. There's nonstop shit to learn,master, and experience. You never know what's gonna come out of that sinkhole or what this weird cute mob is gonna do to you, enough said, buy the game, its really good.
little bit boring but when u have good team it can be fun

Don't Starve Together would be an actually unforgiving game if it wasn't for other players base building independently from you, simply by bumping into another player while in a bad situation means they can either share your fate, you can try passing the mobs attacking you onto them or you both flee, if you follow them long enough you'd find a base or at the very least a campfire for the night (unless they use a torch or other light source).  As far as balance goes I can't recommend single player without mods as the enemies/bosses are scaled up based on player count and as such taking on anything solo without mods is practically suicide unless you're really good at kiting.. even knowing the default movesets for a boss in normal Don't Starve doesn't help so much here as in some cases there are new attacks or outright completely different strategies they use (dragonfly in DST for example is like a mini raid boss).  I can recommend this safely if you like this kind of game and if you're prepared to learn to survive on your own, you'll need some adaptability to prepare for winter and summer safely, caves are suicide for newer players unless you camp the entrance and the rest of the biomes are not too dangerous unless you wander into swamps unprepared.  You do need armour in game to take hits and you shouldn't try to rely on other players as you'll be restricting your own freedom and the best way to learn is to do it yourself or in the presence of somebody more experienced.. so in short you can rely on people for food/rest but don't expect anybody to keep you alive out of obligation, if anything it's more likely due to if you die then your ghost will hit everybody else alive with a sanity draining aura that only goes when you revive.  Overall a great game and i expected nothing less from Klei to be honest, they really know how to make a fun experience alone or with friends and also the game is still being added to and updated so I can recommend this for the long term also. Not going to go into the characters or the balance of them here but the cast is varied and I feel safe enough saying that odds are there is one you will like maybe not at first but eventually and if it clicks (world or character) then you'll be in this for a long time.  Ah and also buying this game nets you 1 free steam gift copy of the game so your friend that is also interested can also join your adventures, there is honestly nothing I can recommend more for survival co-op than this at the moment.. heck I wouldn't want to either this game does so much right and the devs go above and beyond with what they're doing here, if you don't like this particular game at least browse through their other products they really are amazing.

Great game. The developers actually listen and have done a great job evolving the game to what it is today. I started with Don't Starve, before it came onto Steam so I am a long time fan. I was one of many who hoped for a multiplayer version of DS back then and after Don't Starve Together finally came out I've been so happy with it as well as my friends. It is a fun, complex and challenging game and the developers are able to find ways to keep the game interesting while amazing mods for it exist. It has been an awesome experience over the years. There are awesome game mechanics that need to be in EVERY survival game. There's depth to each character and their individual in-game advantages/disadvantages done very well. Surviving with others is great fun, like being a Wickerbottom to farm and create books while a Maxwell does resource gathering with his shadow minions, and book reading. The game rewards those that are observant and can think outside the box, like dropping stacks of food near werepigs for manure or spooking spiders for a guaranteed gland.  There are thousands of things to explore in DST but it's all wrapped in a simple package. My kid has pretty much grew up with DST and is as big a fan as I am. We still look forward to each update. Thank you, Klei! Two thumbs up! d("d)

This is the kind of game you play when you want to actually co-operate with your friends. Resources can be scarce, time is sometimes thin for said resources, and you are either running low on your hunger (wow, who would've guessed that would be in the game) or sanity. The first few times playing may be hard, and you wipe earlier on; this is a game of learning from your mistakes.  Of course, the game also gives customization options for your characters, so you don't necessarily need to always look like the base character. Loot drops occur at least once per day on starting up, and some time after playing in a game.  The game does have microtransactions, one category being the DLC characters, the other being cosmetics. Of course there are plenty characters in the base game to enjoy, so unless you really want them, you don't need to buy the characters. The cosmetics work as either costumes for your character, or re-skins of items you craft in game. The Workshop is also filled with plenty of custom characters and other mods, that missing out on a bit of DLC isn't nearly concerning.

I am going to say that I do recommend this game, at least under certain circumstances.   The game itself (at least from my experience) isn't that different from normal don't starved aside from certain mods or dlc that can be used. So if you are just running solo, you don't have to get the game. Of course, you can just play solo on this too except if you play solo on a game with "together" in the name it feels kinda lonely (help me) so yeah.  Now, if you are playing this with friends, it makes everything so much better (to an extent, will explain later). The multiplayer aspect of the game changed how I played. I normally just hide away from creatures and avoid fights unless absolutely necessary. When I played with friends however, we'd kite creatures and constantly swap aggro if possible and when it wasn't possible, we'd just all rush in and the monster would usually do less damage than it would have normally. We were also able to divvy out tasks for each person. One could hunt for food, another could tend the farm, the third could be cutting down trees, the fourth could be getting stone, etc. It became a very well oiled machine. It can also become very repetitive. As survival games go, Don't Starve Together can be very harsh if you are unprepared. Given how it is a multiplayer game and it can be modded? It becomes almost impossible to survive if you are the wrong character or if you are simply unprepared and with multiple people running it for the first time, it has/causes problems.  During my first few runs with my friends, the first time we made it to winter we had two choices, die of starvation or die of cold. We had been concerned with just surviving temporarily and forgot all about winter and nearly paid the price because we didn't have enough materials to make more than 1 coat/hat. The person going out had to get enough food for 3 people and go get flint for axes. Next winter we had the same problem as we had two new arrivals and we had to now feed and clothe 5 people. It was a very painful existence but I will say the chaos was fun which is why I am recommending this even if it is difficult with several people.  Although, if you have the first game and is considering this one? I don't know how much I can help with that as I don't really play the normal Don't Starve.

---{Graphics}--- ☐ You forget what reality is ☐ Beautiful ☑ Good ☐ Decent ☐ Bad ☐ Don‘t look too long at it ☐ Paint.exe  ---{Gameplay}--- ☑ Very good ☐ Good ☐ It‘s just gameplay ☐ Mehh ☐ Starring at walls is better ☐ Just don‘t  ---{Audio}--- ☐ Eargasm ☐ Very good ☑ Good ☐ Not too bad ☐ Bad ☐ Earrape  ---{Audience}--- ☐ Kids ☐ Teens ☐ Adults ☑ Human  ---{PC Requirements}--- ☐ Check if you can run paint ☐ Potato ☐ Decent ☑ Fast ☐ Rich boiiiiii ☐ Ask NASA if they have a spare computer  ---{Difficulity}--- ☐ Just press ‚A‘ ☐ Easy ☐ Significant brain usage ☑ Easy to learn / Hard to master ☐ Difficult ☐ Dark Souls  ---{Grind}--- ☐ Nothing to grind ☐ Only if u care about leaderboards/ranks ☐ Isnt necessary to progress ☑ Average grind level ☐ Too much grind ☐ You‘ll need a second live for grinding  ---{Story}--- ☐ Story? ☑ Text or Audio floating around ☐ Average ☐ Good ☐ Lovely ☐ It‘ll replace your life  ---{Game Time}--- ☐ Long enough for a cup of coffee ☐ Short ☐ Average ☐ Long ☑ To infinity and beyond  ---{Price}--- ☐ It’s free! ☑ Worth the price ☐ If u have some spare money left ☐ Not recommended ☐ You could also just burn your money Note that when you purchase a copy of DST you get a gift item in your inventory that you can send to a friend!  ---{Bugs}--- ☑ Never heard of ☐ Minor bugs ☐ Can get annoying ☐ ARK: Survival Evolved ☐ The game itself is a big terrarium for bug  ------------ Don't Starve Together is a brilliant addition to your library - even if you own the singleplayer Don't Starve. Not only does it provide countless laughs with your friends (as well as bitter rivalries) but it brings a whole new experience of Don't Starve! While the frustration of dying over and over because of poor choices wails on you, you'll just think about how it's better to do that with friends, than without.

A great survival game. The most attractive feature of DST for me is "option": you always have multiple options to achieve the same end goal. Some options may be more time efficient, some may be more resource efficient, some may be more fun, some may be more demanding control-wise. The game is fun and exciting, the fact that you know nothing when the game starts and you have to find out with trial and error makes everything you haven't seen in the game before both scary and interesting. The art style is rock solid and the fact that it's almost 3d and almost 2d with the flat characters and objects but the ability to rotate the camera gives a certain feel I can't really describe. I'd recommend this to anyone who enjoys difficult and rock solid survival games. I remember when Don't Starve Together first came out and me and my friends could finally play together. It took the original game and expanded on it.   The mini animations dropped here and there on Klei's official youtube channel also add so much to the story and the characters.  The characters, ah the characters. They come together to create a fun and unique crew, their many different quirks makes for so many different playstyles and combinations, just not Wes. Nobody should play Wes.

Why I play this game: Crunchy, satisfying sound effects. Animations are squishy and stretchy. Also satisfying. Thrilling, gritty dangers. No gore or jumpscares. Just running for your life. Specific elements can be reduced or turned off, for anyone tired of dying to That Thing too many times. Specific elements can be boosted or extra boosted, for when an ordinary amount of carrots simply isn't enough. Or if you wanted to die to That Thing even more times. No copy-paste content. Enemies/items all behave differently. Seasons change graphics + survival challenges, so it doesn't get stale. Permanent cosmetics earned via playtime. Light your hair on fire to assert dominance. It's a funny world. Even your own beard is a valuable resource. Map generator keeps it fresh. Some worlds are more terrifying than others. Like the one that spawned 50 aggressive beehives in a single field. The game supports mods! In case a vanilla-flavored death wasn't intense enough for you.  It says it's a survival game, but let's be honest, dying in tragic or absurd ways is a pretty big part of the game. If you can't laugh about it when your entire base burns to the ground, it might not be the game for you. There's a rollback recovery option for maps, but it's rather likely you'll experience camp obliteration sometimes, particularly while learning how the game works. If you can shrug that off, overall, the game is very, very satisfying.

Even if you don't have any friends to play the game with, it's the same as solo player Reign of Giants without a pause and sometimes has a little more lag. In all honesty though, those aspects are completely overshadowed by all the other positives. There are frequent updates, cosmetic options, events, new and different mechanics, and the opportunity to make friends is amazing. In my experience, the player base has been overwhelmingly friendly, and even when we died, we had fun doing it. I've never made it to the end game, but this game, and the solo player experience, have been my all time favorite games.

Its fun, but not friendly to new players!  If you are interested this game is unforgiving at times, but there is and option to turn of or lower things in creating the world or by downloading workshop mods(Some mods are quite drastic, which makes the game too easy at times.) Just watch some tutorials (For example on how to Kiting or crock pot recipes)and install essential mods. Don't pick theese characters as your 1st character: -Wickerbottom -MaxWell -Willow -Wes(For the love of God DON'T pick Wes. He's only for the BEST players :D) Rule nr.1 Don't pick up flowers. Rule nr.2 Don't attack random mobs that are stronger or that are in a pack bigger than 3. Rule nr.3 Don't pick up EVERY food you find. Rule nr.4 Try not to fight without armor. Im pretty sure this summarizes the Basic's of this game :D If i got anything wrong then I am sorry.

A fantastic cooperative survival experience, if frantic is the pace you desire.  A longtime fan of the Don't Starve franchise Don't Starve Together adds the much needed cooperative experience to this benignly adorable, if ruthless, survival experience. I have been very pleased (and even impressed) with the continued publisher support for this title. The added features, zones and updates have really allowed this game to grow into its own as a  FRANTIC OH GOD NO Dear sweet meatballs what is THAT THING and what will it DO to ME?!?! game where winning is nice but really it is the journey with friends through a world of mysteries that I find so enjoyable.  Tying this up: if discovery, looting and frantic nervous chuckles are your thing and you don't mind poking the bear (and getting eaten in so many creative ways) then this is a great isometric experience. Friends are nice to have both for the synergy and teamwork (you will almost certainly need them) and to keep the world fresh and engaging.

Some fight, some  gather, and others make/build up the gear/base.    Damned good game  designed to  make cooperation easy.

Survival games are plentiful, it takes a lot to stand out on this market. I originally got into the alpha/beta of the original Don't Starve not expecting a whole ton but found a wonderful addition to the survival genre. Don't Starve Together is almost like a sequel to Don't Starve and the title does not necessarily mean you have to play with others to succeed as it is still a great game to play alone. The Don't Starve series prides itself on being difficult to learn and that is not a bad thing as once the mechanics are learned, they stick creating a smarter player base that constantly teaches each other how to survive better. Don't let the first hour or even five hours let you down, look around and find out how to play. Knowledge is power in these games which is why fighting is the best of any survival game as you have to learn how to outplay the enemy by use of kiting techniques. I could go on and on about why this game deserves a look, but instead here's the TLDR.  TLDR: The game is fantastic, give it a go and learn from those who have survived before you.

The first good thing is that u get to play with friends or just other random players cooperatively. This game contains elements of exploration, survival, cooking, combat, sandbox, and more. It is very replayable and the experience is better when playing with friends.

Fun game if you don't know what you're doing, gets better once you learn what you're doing. That said it didn't take me too long to actually get a good grasp of what to do. Will say a lot of how enjoyable of your game is can depend on how lucky you are with a spawn.  Characters are all really fun. You can get addicted to playing one or switch between different characters each with unique perks that make it easier or harder to survive depending the circumstances.  Friends really add to the game but not required. As all games it's a lot easier communicating through voice since typing is hard when you're getting chased by a pack of feral dogs.  The game can be quite unforgiving at times with your stats being hard to get up without the right stuff but that's one of the things that can make it more fun if you like that kind of thing. If not, there's workshop support to basically alter or add anything you want.  Cosmetics: All DLC are cosmetics most of which you can weave for free by breaking down the free cosmetics you get. Even then though it's all really cheap especially compared to a lot of cosmetics these days (cough battle royal on origin I'm looking at you). If it's not your cup of tea you can just try ship some of the cosmetics off on the steam market to get some extra cents to full bucks.

[*] Rating: 10/10  This game is amazing. Great Storyline and so much to discover and explore. I can play this over and over and not get bored and it is different every time you play through it. I highly recommend this game as it is one of my favorites.  [*] Graphics: 10/10 The Art Style is absolutely gorgeous and smooth. I have not found issues with this and i've been playing this game for years now.  [*] Music: 10/10 Each characters sound is based on a different instrument which just gives it so much more character, love it.  [*] Story: 10/10 Really interesting storyline. The more you discover, the more you find out about each characters background and the origin of this world.  [*] Controls: 10/10 Easy to figure out and well set.

Awesome game. the art style is a very unique style that you dont see, its very fun to play with friends and even fun to play/practice by yourself. Obviously though its best with friends or randoms and you can meet some great people here. There are some parts of the characters and mechanics in the game that aren't immediatly explained but with a quick search or question to another player they can explain it easily. it also doesn't take long to learn at all. There is also thousands of mods that others have created to customize the game however you wish. for example, different music, want shovel knight? they got that. want paper mario? they got that too. there's thousands and Klei (the people that made this) promote mods made by the players and constantly update and balance the game so can have fun playing any character if you so choose. All and all, its a wonderful gane and definitely recommended to anyone into a group survival type game. (you can also choose to have pvp or turn it off so you dont always have to worry about better players killing you).

Just as much fun as the single-player version... although a lot depends on the host's connection (and maybe your distance from them?) and rubberbanding can be deadly when you keep snapping back to some enemy that's chasing you.  Still, mods that increase health can smooth over some of those bumps.  It's pretty cool to build up a base together, and the atmosphere is definitely different when there's someone else around to help you out and vice versa!  Or when you're thinking, "ha, I finally got some gears, I'll surprise my friend with a fridge back at the base".

I used to find Don't Starve got quite boring when playing in single player but whenever I have played it with friends it has become really fun to try to survive through each night whilst working as a group. You can expect to have a quite a laugh if you play this game with friends and at times, it can be quite the challenge. The game is incredibly thought-out with a linear story and various characters to choose from and progress with. The game has a melancholy and to some extent horrorifying graphical style which sets it apart from many games that follow the same calibre. If you have friends who are willing to play this with you regularly, it's definitely worth giving a shot.
