I think this title certainly deserves something like one of a lot of good survival games, nice "cartoon" graphics, lots of clothes, accessories, skins, but to play, the game is very chaotic for the first few hours, you can easily die, you don't know what build what is good to look for, what ever takes place etc .. but after a few tens of hours you will find that the game really has a lot to offer (on the surface is quite interesting and the game includes a cave, which is defacto 2nd world just twice so big and 2x so diverse) Even after 100 hours you still have something to learn, in this game everything bad is good for something. If wolves are coming at you, you can help them kill pigs and have meat from pigs and wolves, if you run a tree guard, you can use it to kill Goose / Moose, if you play for the first time, over time you understand what I'm saying! : D Good luck in playing, the game has a lot to offer and lots of people are interested, there are a lot of public servers with non-toxic and friendly people who are either there for the first time and do not know or have 3000 hours of play and it's been for them a routine where they just try new and new things and talk to other people. [h1]If someone's not burning your stuff while you're away, you're playing on casual mode.[/h1]  The original single player game was a survival game where every minute makes the difference. The same is true here, but now you have human rng running rampant like it's Wrestlemania. Make friends with the good human rng or you're just asking for trouble.   Sometimes though, a little trouble is a lot of fun.   If you keep in mind that you're going to lose everything on most servers, you'll have a great time. Because, as the Dwarven phrase goes, "Losing is FUN."

I love all things Klei. I seriously have never had a single thing to complain about with any of their games.  Our group had a hard time keeping it "together" when we first tried doing this weekly, and I think my recommendation from it is, do spend some time playing alone first - you can do this in the original or even in Together (they have their slight differences and it's great!!). The point is there is plenty to learn, explore, and die by. I don't die so readily because I have hundreds of hours in the base game, and I think having multiple of the rest of the group dying a lot discouraged us. I know with Turn of Tides out some of us are going to give it another go and I can't wait!

an amazing game hands down. One of the best survival games i've played. The game can be somewhat confusing when you start off, but the community is so friendly and helping that I learnt pretty much everything in a matter of days.   in terms of difficulty, the game gets harder as the number of days increases. So it's a game that's easy to pick up but hard to master. Different characters have different mechanic and play styles, for an example, wortox can teleport, but his hunger drains faster than the other characters, so you and your teammates need to vary the way they play in order to survive.   The game also offers a lot of content. Items, bosses and a lot of status effects during different seasons (overheating during summer and freezing during winter), so you have to adapt. The bosses are tricky to take down as well, so you have to choose whether you want to take it down or run from it.   It has a great artstyle which really brings out the feeling of suffering the characters face throughout the game.   The devs update frequently to balance things out, add new characters, islands, mobs e.t.c.   The game runs well on my laptop, so in terms of specs, it can run fine on any decent device.

This, along with Don't Starve itself, was my favorite game from ~2015 to late 2018. It has simple mechanics but endless replayability. It has rich lore and an immersive world, which is made complete by the stellar and completely novel art design. (Enough cannot be said about this game's art and sound design, which is absolutely unparalleled.)   I have well over 200 hours logged in this game and had a blast with each of them. It was joy to play with both friends and complete strangers, who more often than not were very nice and cooperative.   If you are a fan of survival games, are attracted by this game's unique art style, or are a Don't Starve veteran, then I cannot oversell this game to you.  It will easily grant you 50-100 hours of fun depending on your grit.   Past that, there is one caveat. After 200+ hours in this game, I found myself bored by it, as happens naturally with any game. I only play rarely nowadays, and always with friends. Real-life friends who you can share your experiences with and mentor through this challenging game are what makes this game, so if you have a dedicated friend or two to bring along, then I can doubly recommend this.   Either way, this is a must-buy for anyone remotely intrigued.

I finally gave this game a try recently at the behest of some friends, and I think it's safe to say I can see the appeal. It's easy to fall into the rhythm of gathering supplies and crafting the things you need to survive and banking what you can and then having it all go to shit because the summer heat ignited all your chests and it's getting dark and the hounds are coming and--  Anyway, buy this game. If you like the standalone Don't Starve then you'll probably really enjoy Don't Starve Together. It has all the natural chaos of Don't Starve (lots of dying) with lots of additional twists like pets, mounts (beefalo for the win), and of course multiplayer. However, just because it offers multiplayer doesn't mean you can't still play solo you can set options to play solo or password lock your server so only certain players can join you. Additionally, there is an option to rollback your own servers to start earlier in the day or previous few days (such as if troublesome players came along and your game on purpose or if you have a silly husband who doesn't understand the characters and turns into a werebeaver on day two).

One of the greatest random death generator games I know.  Always have in mind that if you don't plan your exploration well you can always die by meteorites, angry frogs or huge lava spitting flies or starvation, insanity, or whatever the game throws at you. Don't be discouraged though, the game is fun as it can get for those who like the crafting genre. Playing this game with friends creates some memorable moments, trying to distract those one-eyed tall birds while your friends flee after stealing their eggs or making plans of backstabbing those bunnies on steroids that live underground, or even ridiculously chasing turkeys, which for some reason are not that easy to kill with an ax. Those annoying dogs that come around over and over will also test your friendship, as you gather resources to defend yourself and your more reckless friends spend their time trying to collect gnomes or some other collectibles found in graves. This game is definitely a solid investment to consider for those who want some challenge and fun time crafting, exploring and building a base with friends.

Pro Tip: Don't search for Sans or Undertale on the workshop.

This twist on the original's formula makes for a fun multiplayer experience, especially with friends.   Pros: - Multiplayer with both friends, or through hosted/dedicated servers. - Amazing mod support in-game via the steam workshop. Server mods are universal to all players on that server (such as character mods), and client mods only changes your end (UI customization etc). - Large active playerbase means you will always find someone to play with. - Additional features not present in the single player version of the game, such as new or reworked bosses/areas. - Diverse cast of characters allows for neat combinations when playing with others. For example, Wickerbottom can craft spell books that have powerful effects such as regrowing farms/food. Wolfgang loves this, since he needs a LOT of food but is otherwise the strongest fighter of them all. - A "progression" system of sorts in the form of character cosmetics that are earn just by playing. If you don't care for these cosmetics, you can convert them into "spools" for other cosmetics, or even buying the 2 "locked" characters (Wortox+Wormwood) for free. - It's still being actively supported and still receiving free content updates at the time of writing this review.  Cons: - Can be a little laggy. While the game by default tries to "predict" movement client-side, it doesn't always work out and occasionally causes you to get hit from what feels like a mile away. - Public servers are prone to trolls who mess with others for the heck of it. Thankfully, Klei Entertainment had the foresight to include a server rollback option when this happens, so it's more of an annoyance than an issue. - Um, well thats it for issues I found lol.  If you played the original game and liked it, or you know a friend that does, this is a great buy and very much worth it.

This is such a versatile game. Especially if you're willing to use mods, you can do basically anything here. Given the choice between Don't Starve or Don't Starve Together, I would go with Together. There's so much customization and the choice to play multiplayer is great.  The customization allows for a very broad range of difficulty levels. Want to kill all the bosses with minimal supplies? Go ahead. Want to have no bosses and unlimited respawns? Also an option! You can make it as hard or as easy as you want, I think that's the beauty of the game.  My biggest annoyance is that there's no way to cross the water, so sometimes you have to take massive detours. I tried finding a mod that let me make custom wormholes or something similar, but nothing seemed to work. Besides that, I don't really have anything negative to say about the game. Overall I'd say it's pretty well balanced and definitely enjoyable.  EDIT: With the Return of Them update, it is now possible to cross the water, removing the only thing I disliked about DST.

This is an absolutely amazing game. It can be endless hours of fun when you have friends to adventure the constant with. There is a steep learning curve but don't be swayed to stop playing because once you get past that first winter things start getting easier and with the bosses and base building there is tons to do. This is a hardcore survival game so that means if you die its game over but there are ways to get the world to continue progressing but that requires items. I have over 400 hours in this game and still find reasons to revisit it on the occasion to see how far or fast i can do things like beat some of those pesky bosses. In addition to that the devs constantly update the game and with new content on the way there are new adventures awaiting us all. Its a game I couldn't recommend more to the person looking for a nice relaxing evening of hardcore survival with a few good friends to chat with. Although with that in mind someone who likes constant action could still find this game to their liking as there are lots of mobs to hunt and with the forge you can find continuous action. With fighting nuances like kiting and different character mechanics I think this game could find a place in most people's hearts at least for awhile especially if you like other games such as Minecraft or Terraria since they all share the survival, crafting, and fighting elements.

Now, I am gonna be honest with this game.  It was a great experience while trying to improve during my time with the game, and i can admit the developers care a lot of their creations.   The art is interesting, and really fitting with the theme they were going with the game. And it gives it it's sort of feel when you come across a certain mob, making some of them look threatning yet adorable at times. And most of the character skins and look shows a lot.  Now with the gameplay, while it is devastating when playing as a beginner, once you learn the basics then the core of the game, it can be really enjoying because it has a lot options and ways you can play the game, like you wanted to make the game more hard, do a sort of restriction in the game play, like a challenge. Now with the characters, they are very unique and all play a sort of role, for example, Wickerbottom can a supportive yet powerful game changing character, due to her having books which can skip all the wait and preparation for a certain supply or a fight. Now they all have a certain disadvantage which affects the character's stats and viability. Some of these characters could use a rework by any sort or change. Now with the rest of the game, it gives a sort of challenge in every season, autumn will usually be the starting season, and there will be no sort of disadvantage. Now with winter, it can be one of the most harshest seasons. Because if you are unprepared for winter, then there's barely any sort of chance for you to survive. Each season has their own disadvantage (Within the second coming of autumn, there is a seasonal boss which can be disastrous if not dealt with.) Which forces you to prepare for. The amount of knowledge and learning you have to go through from each season and enemies gives a feel of enjoyment because you are learning on how to fight through these game changing problems. The combat and enemies are nearly the most exiting parts yet most frustrating. You normally just take the damage, but in order to actually succeed taking a specific enemy, you have to learn to kite. It's normally doing damage to a enemy while not taking actual damage. And a lot of these enemies can be annoying, or can be easily dealt with. Bosses in these games are extremely enjoying, because you have to prepare and make sure any sort of disadvantage is dealt with. These bosses can be extremely punishing or extremely easy depending on your preparations. And each season has their own seasonal bosses, 2-3 of these seasonal bosses are a hassle to deal with if your not ready. One of them can be Deerclops, winter's seasonal boss. It breaks structures and tries to hunt down the player.   The multiplayer is great but has some problems. In multiplayer, you can join a variety of servers depending where you are living. And most of these can be searched from filtering and specifically searching it. You can also host your own, and add settings and changes to the server. When you join a certain server, everything is the same, besides there's players instead of a single one. You can chat with these players. What i would recommend for you to do is to find a server that is currently in the first autumn as in Day 1-10 that is team cooperating and social. This will guranteed give you a chance to survive with a team attempting to survive through these seasons. And each player has to be benefitting the team by doing the characters purpose and role.   Now the problems with multiplayer is annoying. I haven't found or discovered any sort of bugs, besides abusable ones. The main problem with game is normally beginners. Because most of the beginners just instantly go to multiplayer and not aware of being unexperienced with the game. And would be either kicked or just get carried, or stay dead then leave. Some players do teach these beginners and giving them tips, but mostly kick them for eating up resources and doing nothing or not fulfilling their role. For every beginner, i would absolutely recommend watching guides, tutorials from DST youtubers. The community itself, is alright. And the most frustrating part of multiplayer is griefers. Now this problem can be easily solved, and can be reversed when a griefer lights something on fire or hammers the base. But they can usually time their destruction to the next day, making rollback useless to reverse the damage. And the server will usually die. Some of these servers reset, deleting every piece of progress, starting it at day 1. The lag can be annoying but then just goes back to normal  Concluding this detailed review, i totally recommend this game because it has a lot of options and challenges to give, and can be very addictive and enjoying, as well with friends. And you can play in your style. If you are starting out in this game, i recommend just watching guides and tutorials before playing multiplayer.

If you're into stat management, inventory management, and crafting games, then you'll definitely enjoy this game.  You will need to not only manage your health and hunger, but also lighting, sanity, and your very tools in order to survive.  Get too hungry? Starve to death. Go insane? Shadows manifest abhorrent creatures to consume your being. Don't have light when night falls? The Matriarch of the darkness will strike when you least expect.   Couple with events, DLC, cosmetics, and a steady influx of new characters with unique abilities, strengths, and weaknesses (as well as occasional reworks of old ones, including previously DLC-exclusive characters from Don't Starve), you can certainly tell Klei is taking care of this game.

The gameplay cycle is simple: explore the world and gather materials during the relative safety of daylight, survive the night by crafting a fire and consuming some food, repeat. And while there's a fair amount of mundanity associated with that, those efforts culminate in desperate and tense struggles for survival. In one game I found myself low on supplies and pursued through the woods by a horde of vicious spiders. Realizing there was little hope for escape, I threw caution to the wind and started a nearby tree on fire. Frighteningly quickly, the entire forest went up in flames, and my attackers were all reduced to piles of silk... which I picked up and used to make a vest. This game is very fun 8/10, i do not recomend playing this game alone... it has the word "Together" for a reason.

Don't Starve is a survival game which throws you into the wilderness, with no hints at how to survive. There is a steep learning curve, but thanks to the amazing animation and kooky sense of humour it is well worth the effort. Don't Starve Together gives you the added benefit of being able to play online with other players. This can be both a blessing and a curse, so be careful about who you join up with.  Pros ------- Different world every time A selection of weird & wonderful characters to play - each with their own strengths & weaknesses Beautifully animated A crazy, immersive world Beefalos (they even have their own song on YouTube)  Cons -------- Is becoming increasingly monetized Online play can mean problems with lag  Can get frustrating when you plateau Time seems to disappear when you play  I absolutely love this game & highly recommend it.

Don't Starve Together is a fun, interesting, and challenging survival game that adds onto the survival genre as a whole. The music, art style, and small creative choices helps this game breath with originality and let's it shine in it's own way. The game play is challenging to first understand, but, with practice, you'll begin dominating your worlds. The developers care about their game and have events and upcoming updates planned and have already been steadily releasing some. Not to mention, you earn marketable items through play time that can be sold on the community market. I'd reccomend this game to any who loves survival games, especially during this sale (Summer 2019) where you get a free copy of the game to gift to a friend.

A fantastic game !  It actually took me some time to give this game a shot until i saw it being for sale and so i took my chance. Seriously i dont even regret that decision at all , besides some "small" things more for that later.  The artstyle is fantastic and i like those creatures and giants or those characters you can play,each with their own pro and cons and different stats.  Your main goal is to survive as long as possible and trying to get rid of those constant threats ,which are seasons ,giants or invasions and trying to avoid starvation or becoming insane,which can be sometimes really challenging ,but to make it even more challenging there are also players ,that tends to griefing by lighting your base on fire ,destroying stuff in there or just stand at base (,which you build to have an easier time or you play nomad style )and keep eating off your supply and ressources off in no time and trust me a lot of people do that and if you dont have people, that do stuff to surive together you find yourself rather being frustrated and annoyed from the game.  Actually there are people ,that complains that the community is toxic and ,if someone get seens/called griefing/griefer.He gets kicked rather quick from the server ,which some trolls tends to abuse.The big problem in this game are those people you play on random servers,which can make all your effort useless ,but i also gotta say ,that you barely get any information about what to cook or not ? for example. You can make crockpots to cook food. Sounds simple right ? Yes it is , if you know the proper recipes.You can get with 4 ingredints quite a lot of different foods,if you missplaced them or took too many of another one.So if you dont spent time on wiki or finding people ,that help you through the game.You might find yourself frustrated and hating on this game and may gonna say it's the worst game you ever bought for that price.  Still for that you can play with friends together and try to learn the game together ,which is a lot of fun and in general i recommend doing so to avoid randoms people,since 80% of them are trolls/griefer/eater aka just staying at base and eating everything ,thats in the fridge just like in real life :^)   However i still gonna recommend this game.Just because it's an amazing survival game with interesting ideas for characters and mechanics and lots of hidden secrets and quite a lot of stuff to discover or to learn,but there is one more thing ,that i might want to add.  This game has mod support ,which adds new characters into the game with their own functionality and QoL changes or more content in general.

How do you even write a review for a game like this, It doesn't need a review or recognition of how good it is. IT NEEDS A [b]F*CKING AWARD![/b]  Although I agree with most reviews that It can be time-consuming and very tedious with every action you make within the game, its what makes the game special. The Steam Store needs more games likes this, more games with a challenge, a set checklist that is basically set off RNG and pure luck of your spawn location. Its not a game where you can constantly memorise where to go and what to do at all times of the day/dusk/night. Its not a pesky little game that costs $21 and takes 2 hours to complete and accomplish all achievements, its a game you have to work for and utilise your patience. And most importantly, its a game you can always come back to and accomplish just as much as when you left last.

Oh boy, another survival game for me to boot.  This game won't hold your hand for every little things that you do. You're basically free to do whatever you want! That doesn't mean you're up for a good time, though.  Being free to do everything doesn't mean you're allowed to do everything. Especially those who don't wanna learn how to stay alive in the game.  Unless you poured some hours onto the game, expect a non-forgiving survival, an uncompromising adventure of being stranded somewhere and forced to survive, gather resources, stave off hunger, and last but not least, hug the comforting fire pit that soothe your dreary night ahead while slowly losing your sanity.  IF, and IF, you're a survivalist type, this game is not too different from your usual cup of joe. I've played some harder survival game than this, but this game is definitely a start for newcomers, if they wanna learn the hardship of survival game while playing with different characters of one and another.  Main Wickerbottom? Immediate crafting for your former days and books usage for the latter. Main Wendy? Weak in term of hand-to-hand fighting, but a go-to if you want a friendly ghost that do stuff for you. Main Wigfrid? Those mobs won't stand a chance against your valkyrie might... but you despise veggies on your diet.  There are couple of ways to survive, and that is if you're playing alone.  It's called "Don't Starve TOGETHER", by the way. You're not alone, if multiplayer session is your choice. People across the world, or across your sofa, will be pitted in the same land to survive. Will you cooperate together and face the darkness, or, instead of trusting them of your well-being, you annihilate them, crush them like a bug, and force them outta the server because you're too good at fighting? There are times when you just wanna login and hangout, chat a bit, play it smooth and not to worry with dying, and luckily the game provides you with that as well, phew. What was that? I hear you just wanna watch the world burn thanks to your torch? Suit yourself in 'Madness' section and wreck havoc for your silly little enjoyment. Let your inner pyromaniac go do their thing, will ya?  You main Wes? Get ready to get hanged. NO. WES = BAD. NO WES, PLEASE. FILTHY WES MAIN, STAY AWAY FROM ME, YOU DISGUSTING CREATURE. AAAAAAA-

As Wilson, grow a boring beard and watch everyone else do cool things with their abilities while shaving your beard.  As Willow, burn Wilson's base after stealing all of his food, then cook the food with your lighter and when you eventually go insane because the Wilson is haunting you drop your teddy bear Bernie Sander and watch it grow into a enormous size and slaughtering your living nightmares with universal healthcare.  As Wolfgang steal all of Willow's food and eat it all in one go to become mighty then go insane because of Willow's ghost but kill your living nightmares by yourself and go to youtube and make videos on why it's good to always be insane until you get killed by your living nightmares while fighting a boss and go complain on youtube and quit the game.  As Wendy use the power of your stand 「A B I G A I L」to farm spiders and hounds until Abigail decides to run off and attack a group of Mermmen but get's gang raped by them and dies again.  As WX steal and eat your friends gears that they were planning to make fridges out of and beg the Wickerbottom to electrocute you so you become even more OP, but then die when she uses the tentacle book on you because you stole gears.  As Woodie chop wood and make chests out of that wood, chop more wood and put that wood into the chest and make more chest once its full then become the werebeaver and run into the dragonfly and become beaver meat.  As Waxwell summon more stands to chop trees and fight for you but die once they die because you forgot how little HP you have.  As Wigfrid sell battle spears and helmets for meat but then die of starvation because everyone got football helmets and tentacle spikes instead.  As Webber set up your spider base in the middle of nowhere and cause a civil war but then accidentally set the nest on fire and die because there was a forest around it.  As Winona build spotlights as they are the best technology in the world and dodge a hit from Charlie while in the darkness because you craft slower than everyone else when you have less than 50 hunger and then die from starvation because it costs 5 hunger to craft above 50 hunger for a mere 0.5 second faster crafting speed.  As Wortox kill everything and eat their souls and heal with the souls and commit you are already dead by teleporting behind bosses. I loved Don't Starve, and once I learned they were coming out with a game that let you play that same experience but with your friends; I was already sold. There's nothing more fun than spending a summer season clowning around with your friends to being murdered by a giant deerclops while freezing to death in the winter. Workshop support allows for a bit of extra tuning, and you're also allowed to adjust the world however you please on top of that through in game settings.   Bored friends and need something to kill time? This games it.

Originally I chose to ignore this game, thinking that it was something that I wouldn't like.  However, my daughter found it interesting and pointed out that there was a two for one offer, so I bought the two pack.  We've played the game together and I find it rather entertaining.  The music is quite good, hauntingly so, and adds to the ambiance of the game.  The atmosphere that the game presents appears to be something akin to Victorian Gothic, and the cartoony display of the characters lends to the overall playability of the game.  Overall, I'm glad that my original impression of the game has been proven wrong.  I would recommend it for anyone that likes survival-type games.

Don't Starve Together (along with its counterpart Don't Starve) have become by far one of my favorite games ever. The value is there in every capacity. Gameplay, story, characters, graphics/visuals, replayability, DLC/mods, sounds/music, and everything else is genuinely top notch. The game is challenging but not insurmountable, an amazing co-op (many say its co-op is better than single player), endearing but also thrilling and I could go on forever about all it's qualities. If you like survival or crafting games, you will love this game. I'd be shocked if you didn't, no matter what kind of games you like.

Don't Starve Together is an incredibly hard but fun rogue-like multiplayer game where teamwork means everything to one's survival. Taken straight from Edgar Allen Poe's fever dreams, a scientist named Wilson follows instructions given by a mysterious voice out of his radio. After having built a mysterious machine, he powers it on and it warps him to a world unknown to him. Wilson and his friends encounters many dangers in the wild as they try to find their way back home. And this time you get to enjoy the adventures online.  One thing you should know about this game is you're going to die. A LOT. Every time you die however, you'll have learned something new and you're going to come up with a new strategy to beat the game. But every time you think you've got it this time, you'll encounter new dangers and it's back to the drawing board. Don't Starve will not sit you down to read the instructions and expects you to find out what to do on your own. This steep learning curve provided me with many trips to the Don't Starve wiki. From playing with friends however, I also found value in the Steam Workshop, which comes with many fun custom characters to play, useful tools and game hacks to make the game a little less perilous. It should be said that I have never beaten the game before and it's so hard I've not even bothered with the DLC yet but it's still one of my favorite games on Steam. Definitely give it a try!

One of games that lets player craft his own story in a procedurally generated world.   My game play experiences are based on dying over and over again, thus finding more and more patterns and strategies relevant to survival. However essential parts of game are also hidden away from plain sight, thus I had to study resources outside of game.  Downside is that this game is a time sink - you can't pause without exiting game and quitting game midway breaks game play flow. Thereby DST encourages long game play sessions without any breaks, lasting for many hours.
good game

This is a very difficult game to review.  On one hand, this game is extremely difficult and will probably destroy any new player that approaches it, as the game offers next to no help to newcomers.  On the other hand, the game becomes extremely fun once you start to learn its mechanics, and probably one of the realest [b]survival[/b] there is. This game WILL try to kill you, regardless of the situation.   In the end I recommend the game to anyone that has the will to go and learn what it has to offer without backing down instantly in the face of its challenges.

A great way to spend an evening with your friends, trying to survive the world in DST when (no spoilers lol) the weather itself is probably your most dangerous enemy. By that I mean, compared to other enemies that you can kite, run away from, aggro to others, gang up on, you can't really run away from the cold or heat unless you've been diligently stocking up on seemingly useless things from previous seasons.   Also (my friends disagree but) getting insane is probably not the best idea, in this game or otherwise.   It's really addictive gameplay that easily brings back your adventurous spirit as you navigate and explore the world around you - a world all to yourself, free for you to do whatever you want with it, provided that you stay alive. Best to go blind into this game, and the slow but enjoyable learning process comes naturally as you spend hours into the game without realizing.   P.S: May have over-embellished my own experience but it's a game worth the price and the time. Played with friends or otherwise.

The original Don't Starve game was a quirky and charming little game, that while a bit rough (hard and unforgiving to a point), I grew to love as I played. I'm happy to say that Don't Starve Together is more of the same exciting fun, but with friends. The game contains some new content only found in it, such as new boss creatures, and provides a different kind of fun with friends in tow. I highly recommend this game, even if you have no one to play with, but is a sure fire buy if you know someone on your list who already has it.

A new world, a new adventure.  I love the dark aesthetic and the creativity that's put in each character. Each character has a different play-style, and it feels like playing a whole different game whenever you pick a different character: it makes it refreshing and very replayable. There's also quite a number of synergies between characters, and different strategies can be employed depending on which characters are available. Due to the nature of some harder creatures in the game, it is highly recommended to play with more players. Solo-playing can be fun and challenging, but it gets stale over time.  The most fun I have playing this game is with friends. Each new world feels like a rush, and each player has a significant role in the very critical stages of the early game. Teamwork is the key to survival. It's definitely a game made to be played with friends.

Still very fun to play with friends, and playing with strangers can add a lot of competition.

[h1]Positives[/h1] [list] [*] Sandbox playstyle [*] Unique characters [*] Great art style [*] Never a dull moment [*] Free content and updates [/list]  [h1]Negative[/h1] [list] [*] Steep learning curve [/list]  TLDR; [strike]Don't Starve Together (DST) is a great game to feel like you are in control of your own life.[/strike] (I'm joking!) DST is great for people who wants to co-operate with others to learn how to overcome an environment that is out to get you. It is both a co-operative game and a man vs system game.  [h1]Positives[/h1] [u]Sandbox playstyle[/u] DST is like minecraft, where there are many things to do. Harvesting, fighting, exploring, maintaining a base, etc etc. It is a game that allows the player to form their own goals/tasks. It is easy to get immersed in the world and lose many hours in one session of playing.   Despite playing 40+ hours, I still feel as if that I have not seen half of what the game has to offer!  [u]Unique characters[/u] It is rare these days, to have characters that are uniquely different from each other. (That being said, the game isn't very good at explaining the difference. It might be better to read up on what each character have to offer via the wiki.) The starting characters aren't just visual but each of them bring something different to the game and subsequently the server. Some characters excel in certain areas of the game and finding which one fits an individual playstyle is certainly a game all on its own.   Each character is also defined by an instrument and it is fun to not only see but also hear the difference!  [u]Great art style[/u] I mean, have you seen the screenshots? The characters, monsters and world is styled so differently from other games that it is easy to recognise the game through screenshots. Furthermore, the game love its puns in the name. (My personal favourite is [spoiler] Deerclops[/spoiler])   [u]Never a dull moment[/u] The game world is constantly changing. There are many things to learn and the moment you think you got the hang of it, the seasons changes, and each season brings their own troubles and benefits and everything in between.   [u]Free content and updates[/u] When I first picked up the game, I wasn't expecting that there were still future content to come. Especially when it is rare these days to not just ship them as a separate DLC. A big thank you, for the huge amount of content that we currently have and new stuff to come!  [h1]Negative[/h1] [u]Steep learning curve[/u] I only really have one, and that is the fact that it is not an easy game to introduce to new players. It is hard to balance the line between handholding and wanting to pass down important tips to a friend. I love the fact there are several ways to go about acquiring knowledge.   There is the wiki route, where even the wiki itself is massive and it is very easy to get lost in there. And that with the crafting system, there are layers to many knowledge that is offered.   There is the trial and error route, which takes more time but is very addicting. The feeling of knowing or learning something without any help is a huge morale and fun boost.   Otherwise, it is a great game to play with other clueless friends and be proud as both you and them learn the ways to navigate this world!

Day 1 - Collect some supplies and run across the island, I burn down trees and get charcoal. Yum Yum! Day 2 - I get this strange science machine and instantly, I get the better version because yay. Day 3 - I find chess robots who wanna kill me so I kill them in their sleep. Day 4 - I find a sack. I run and supply some more. Day 5 - I jump in a butthole to a different space. Day 6 - Set up camp. Firepit, Really good machine, Fridge, tent. Day 7 - I go hunt for the fancy pancy hat machine. Day 8 - Build it. Day 9 - I make me an effigy with my bear hair.  Skip to day 21 since all I do is harvest and get ready. Day 21 - Cold Winter comes and I am ready. I hunt some food with pigs and find a sheep. Nice. Day 22 - My two iceboxes and 6 crockpots aren't enough for me and 6 pigs. I make a pigwar and collect the droppings.  Day 25 - I shave and kill some cows for a lovely hat.  Day 26 - Hounds come and screw me up. Day 27 - I am weak, no fuel and all I got is twigs. Day 28 - I am freezing to death  Day 29 - I die but I be back.  Day 30 - I pick up my stuff and hunt for fuel. Day 31 - Deerclops comes, and fricks up my base. Day 32 - I die and cry.  overall i think this is a nice game when it comes to survivng.

There is literally nothing I could say about Don't Starve Together that hasn't been said. I absolutely love this game and just about everything about it. It's playable solo but of course better with friends. Considering for 15$ you get two copies of the game that is still being supported by the devs and has tons of workshop content, there's not much to lose here.  My only suggestion to new players is to either watch some videos on setting up basic survival and what to expect for each season or just learn by going with the blows and expect to die... alot.

I really like this game! I especially love the base building aspect combined with the survival aspect. By the way, if you're someone who wants to buy this game reading this right now, the game will probably seem very hard at first, but you can make it easier for yourself by changing the world settings before generating the world. Things like longer day, more recources and of course endless mode will make it way easier for you to learn to survive in the hostile don't starve worlds. Also looking for tips on youtube and the don't starve wiki can also do you wonders. Just watch out on youtube, there's some good youtubers, but there's a few toxic ones you should avoid like Edgy Rick. Overall I recommend this game.

Don't let the charming hand drawn, Tim Burton/Roman Dirge inspired graphics lead you into believing this game is in any way casual or easy, because it's not.   It's tedious, frustrating and impossible for many to even survive their 1st winter.  I think that's part of what makes this game interesting. Unlike most survival games, this one is actually challenging for you to survive. In fact, it's so challenging that it can drive players to the point of delusional paranoia and boot you from servers if they convey you as trying to sabotage their current game.  Because of this, I suggest only playing with friends, or single player mode.  The developers are great, and work to release a steady stream of updates and new content as needed.

If you are looking for a great open world, sandbox, survival and multiplayer game, then Don't Starve Together is the game you should buy. This game not only has unique artwork that makes every character and object look outstanding and unique, it also has very thoughtful ideas that make this game better than any other survival, open world, sandbox, and multiplayer game. This game is exciting, challenging, and fun to play for many hours, this game also provides countless opportunities and very many ideas for you and your friends to have lots of excitement. Don't Starve Together has one of the most unique and special artwork for the game, the art really fits the style of the game and it really makes the design and idea for the game stand out above any other survival or open world multiplayer game. You should get Don't Starve Together not only because it has very many exciting and fun things to do with your friends it also has a cool and unique design and feel to the game. I totally recommend this game to anyone who is looking for a game to play with their friends and to have lots of fun in a unique and amazing game.

I first bought this game in the mega pack for PS4. I had been looking forward to the local co-op since none of my friends had the game and I would be the first of them to try it. I loved it as I had hoped, but ended up playing the single player version more on PS4. My friends could not always play and I really have no desire to pay for Playstation Plus. I got the mega pack around when Wortox was released and not being able to purchase and play him really killed playing Together alone for me on PS4. It took chasing the Hamlet DLC for me to purchase a bundle on Steam and I don't regret it. All the features denied to me on PS4 I finally have access to and I am loving it. Too bad none of my friends can really play with me on this version like PS4. I suppose if there is some grand conclusion from my experience, it is that it is a great game; it is just that different platforms have pros and cons for this game and if you are interested in DLC it is for the single player version. That last part is a pro or a con depending on your preference, but I tend to be a fan of DLC for games I like. I would pay for it if I can access it, which I suppose is what the closet and special characters are for Together.

A fairly challenging survival game with a retro look.  Definitely worth a look if you like oddball survival games. Each world is randomly generated, so you run into different challenges each game. Each character has their own unique abilities and perks which adds to the randomness. Multiple layers of the game add to the fun. Explore caves and deal with different seasons. Watch out for winter as the bitter cold slowly kills you. The brutal summers melt you and burn everything around you. No single dimensional difficulty here folks.  Pick this game up period.

Review:  Pros: + Beautiful graphic + Not so easy survival with a lot of elements (weather, beasts, biotops...) + Lot of content and events  Cons: - In some cases very frustrating (for exam. You are boulding your base and suddenly there is huge monster with obssesion to destroy only your base) - Slow movement  Summary: This game is absolutely neccesary for every group of friends. Yeah you will cry, if your base get destroyed, but this is survival game. And ways of destiny are unpredictible. From me thumb up.

I've easily become obsessed with this game!   It's definitely always a struggle playing games with friends, and this one is no exception. Deciding who will get to eat next if there isn't an abundance of food is never a simple task, especially when you will all nearly end up suffering as a result. I've always wanted to play Don't Starve, and I feel that playing Together will give me the overall knowledge and skills that I will need to be successful playing on my own in the future.   This game is definitely based upon trial and error for those who don't look at online guides to be successful in games, and my only wish was there to be some sort of opening tutorial, to get first time users acquainted to the style and overall functions of the game easier.  Overall, I highly recommend this game to all.

This game is a great one emphasising both on teamwork and survival. I f you like survival games I would recommend this for you as you have to manage hunger, health and sanity. I love the fact that this game is filled with lore behind each and every character (more for some than others), as well as the fact that each and every character feels completely unique with Willow (The Firestarter) who takes longer to overheat but is quicker to cool down and starts with a teddy and a lighter, as well as Webber (The Indigestible) who can befriend spiders and upgrade their dens. Even though this is game is called Don't Starve Together it can be played alone (as I often do so) or with friends meaning you can share this experience with your friends. If you really want to play by yourself I would recommend Don't Starve as you can get extra content and new characters from DLCs (2-6 pounds I think) such as Shipwrecked which involves your characters being shipwrecked at the start and allows from the creation of boats and new characters and bosses along with new creatures.

This one is a sticky wicket. I love the games because they are super fun, but the together version keeps having its ups and downs. My personal experience with it isn't that good partially because everyone I've ever played with aren't cooperative, and when I try playing with my friends the connection goes awful. I also have had problems with the events and cosmetics system. While I like it and all, I don't like the idea of paying for things other than the base game. Events with the Forge got me upset because they were only limited time things and unfortunately they had some really cool cosmetics that were only available during the time. Other than that, it is a good entertaining game, and if you can run it, its good. Is it worth 15 dollars? If you can run a stable server and your friends have the game too, then it is worth every penny. Thanks for reading, educated buyer.

Absolutely love this game. It is a favorite of mine and I always enjoy coming back to it and starting a fresh playthrough. It's a fun and entertaining survival game filled with challenges that you can take on alone or with friends. The art style is unique and gives off Tim Burton vibes as many others have stated. At times, the game can either be relaxed, or outright crazy and challenging. All of the characters have their own unique strengths and weaknesses which create diverse and exciting challenges for the player. Each season in the game creates an even bigger challenge as you fight the weather and hope you don't die.  Overall, funfunfunfunfun. Love it.

Prepare to die multiple times before you learn how to play this game. Then prepare to die multiple times yet again because you just happened to forget to set up that ice flingomatic and now all your belongings are gone.  Grab a couple friends or dare to play it alone, Don't Starve Together is a great continuation of the original Don't Starve. I can highly recommend this game for it's countless hours of fun, quirkiness and many different possible ways to play.   8.5/10.

(Disclaimer: I have never made it past 1 year in the game because I suck at it, so some of the more advanced information might be incorrect)  [h1]Design[/h1] The game has that nice old-school-silent-movie look to it with a good looking hand-drawn art style.  [h1]Gameplay[/h1] I find it best to go into the game blind and learning it all yourself [spoiler]The game is really hard by default, which is part of the fun, there is many things you need to keep track of and there is always something you need, be it something that will make surviving easier or something to fix something that has gone wrong like your food garden lighting on fire somehow. Often you need to make tough decisions like "should I eat this meat raw and risk future starvation or risk starving now so I can cook it so it fills me up for longer?" or "Should I eat this to keep myself from starving at the cost of taking damage?" or "Should I kill this taking damage or die in the process but possibly gain some good food to keep me fed for a while?" There are many fun and charming characters to pick from, none are better than each other but have their own advantages and disadvantages, they all have their own personality and play-styles. There are 4 seasons, each with their own challenges to overcome, freezing in the winter, insanity in the spring, overheating in the summer, and then there is autumn which is kind of your short break from the chaos to make sure you are prepared to do it all again. Your progression in the game does not come the game itself, but rather what you have learned, what to eat and what not to eat, how to make food into the best possible other food.[/spoiler]  [h1]Story[/h1] The game has a deep lore which comes after the story of "Don't Starve". I am not skilled enough at the game to reach the end of either and thus am not the right person to ask, play the game yourself or watch it on youtube if you want.

Don't Starve Together's visuals are STUNNING bringing Burtonesque elements into an explorable world! The controls are pretty tight and take little to no time getting used to. I would say that this game is a mix of survival/horror, strategy, and top-down combat. There are very few bugs that I have found within the 400 hours I have invested in this game so far. Playable characters have diverse mechanics that assist and support different playstyles. The humor in this game is subtle and hilarious. The game is fairly easy to mod for as well!  The music, world, and visuals tie together with a nice, neat, pretty bow. The mechanics are simple and there is no tutorial. The game itself if built to be explored and pokes and prodded at. I have logged hundreds of hours into this game and I am still learning new things!  Don't Starve Together is challenging without being awfully rage-inducing and allows the player to find multiple different ways to survive. It is a pleasant and enjoyable experience for anyone who loves the macabre!

Okay, so this game might not be for you if you're more into solid goals and objectives. Survival is a long-term objective and has way too many possibilities, you know? I tried playing this game with a bunch of first-timers and they were not having a good time. But as someone who has played the single-player mode quite a bit, HOOOO BOIII am I having a heck of a time.   You learn a lot from other players, you can fight together, and you gain a sense of companionship. What better way of feeling a sense of human connection than having someone feed you some nice warm food? I died earlier today because one of my fellow players was freezing and I tried to harvest some silk to make them a winter hat. No regrets :)  I would say the game has a bit of a learning curve since there are a lot of items that can be made. It definitely helps to have some recipes in your head especially because DST does not have a pause functionality. So this tip is for you, newbies: GO FIND SOME FLINT. - Flint + twigs = Axe -> Wood -> FIRE.  - Flint + twigs = Pickaxe -> Stone (and more flint!) -> FIRE PIT. See where I'm going with this?  Also some other principles I have in mind when I play: - If you find a road, try following it. It may not lead to anything fruitful but you gain extra movement speed on roads so might as well utilize it to explore more. - Poop is your friend. Bucket of poop is a better friend! - One of the first items you might want to try making is a garland. Watch your sanity! - Read the wiki in your free time and expand your knowledge. It will help.  Today I almost survived winter. Tomorrow I hope I can stay alive to tell the story. :P

Don't Starve is a great survival game with hidden story, and Don't Starve Together takes us further along in that story. I really enjoy playing DST, and have a fun time just logging on and playing on a random server. I often play on endless just to revive easily and not really have to worry about consequeces (except of course when your health is capped at 25% of your original health if you don't have Booster Shots). The workshop is very interesting too, seeing as you have client side and server side mods (I personally recommend the screaming rabbits mod, it's client side and makes all of the rabbits scream like grown men). The character customization is also the cherry on top for me, because I always like to give the characters my own personal touch. Long story short, Don't Starve Together is a great survival game, and I would recommend it.

I love this amazing game. The only change I would like to see is a Maxwell rework. I have started playing as him more recently, but his shadow fighters are useless later on. I would love to see if you could upgrade them to make them more useful, or specify them for certain bosses.

The art style is very charming, and so is the game play and characters. Though not everything is perfectly balanced, with some things needing serious nerfs and others needing buffs, it's still a nice experience which is even better with friends. (though lets be honest, how many of us have those? ha.   ha.         yeah...)  I will be honest, the multiplayer in most steam games I've played (excluding dedicated servers) is outright @$&*. Many of the other games I play suffer unbearable lag in multiplayer. This game is not one of those. The multiplayer runs very smoothly, regardless of who you may be playing with, and regardless of if it's hosted or if it's a dedicated server. (I have a friend who lives on the other side of the world and this is the only game we can play together without lagging to death) For those of you without friends, worry not! The multiplayer is not limited to friends only. There are many public worlds that you can hop into and meet new friends in! I can't guarantee that the people you'll meet will be friendly, though. It is survival of the fittest, after all.  The world customization is one of the best I've ever seen. Slight warning though: some of the settings are touchy (setting some resources to appear more often makes them practically flood the world, and setting some to appear less might make them practically nonexistent.)  The game's server-by-server modding is a very nice feature. I don't have to enable or disable mods each time I load up a different world, and can have different configurations for each one. It doesn't have world seeds, though, so cherish any world you generate that has a great start location.  This game is by no means easy, of course. If you've played the original Don't Starve, lots of the things in the world have gotten massive health boosts, which spells out doom for people trying to play alone. If you're not too good with these levels of challenges (like me) or don't have many friends to play with (also like me until a few days ago), I'm sure the workshop has something for you.  I give it a thumbs up.

Would Strongly Suggest!  The Dont Starve games are one of the most interesting survival games I have played. Lets start with the stats you have to maintain. Health: one of the many things that make DST difficult for new players is maintaining health, you see , you dont regain HP over time as any character. Making the only way to heal your self is with certain healing items or food. Hunger: In DST you can make a Crockpot which allows you to make all different kinds of food to help raise or even Decrease your stats. Next is the most unique and interesting stat of DST is... Sanity your right you can go insane in this game! Your Sanity decreases at night, dusk and in other scenarios! Its important to keep your Sanity levels decent or else you might be given a visit by a Shadow Creature. These Menaces are one of the only sources of Nightmare fuel a valuable and important resource, note that they aggressive but are easy to fight. Theres a Day-Night Cycle in DST aswell and during Day its normal usually but it depends on the season. In Dusk its a warning of the upcoming Night. In Night you better have a light source because it becomes pitch-black and if your caught without light the Nightmare Monster Charlie comes and if not prepared will 1 shot you. In every season is a Boss at the Beginning Middle or End. Each of the 4 bosses cannot be approached but it comes to you at the designated time. Each boss is designed to be simular to the according season. Bearger is for Autum Bearger is a Bear mixed with a Badger and will eat all of your Winter ration if not taken care of, but drops a resource unique to itself that will aid you in Winter if used right. The Deerclops is the winter boss he will usually come around the night of day 30 or 31 and will warn you of its arrival with deep breathing to warn. He will drop his eyeball that can be used for a Over-Powered hat umbrella known as the Eye-Brella. Beware of his Huge -200 Sanity per min Aura. In the Spring bosses case the Moose-Goose is optional granted that she spawns with her ducklings at certain Moose-Goose spawning locaitons. Beware of her dis-arming honk but also after death her ducklings will become hostile and attack but also granted feathers for the next seasons use.The feathers best use is for a weapon that summons tornados but also can be used to make a fan. In Summer the Antlion is your next foe. She isnt exactly necessary to fight but is a pain if not fed with trinkets and rocks or killed. If not pleased she will created sinkholes or if underground earthquakes, warned but the screen shaking. Interesting fact the Singleplayer version of DST known as just DS (Dont Starve) the original Summer boss was Antlion but she dosent come after you like the others but beware shes a raid boss which also means shes a stronger boss.  Next and last subject is The Seasons them selves an the dangers that follow. Autum: known to be a calm passing period no real dangers. Winter: Extreme cold, if not supplied with warmth, will kill you easily. Spring: known to be a harsher passing period due to the constant rain which can cause Freezing and Insanity. Summer: Extremely Hot, the heat isnt a problem alone wild fires can happen at random causing your base to engulf in flames in not prepared with a Ice-Flingomatic (Fire exstinguishing machine.)  That was a little bit Info compared to the games size (This Review dosent include Combat Methods, Charecter guides and Cave Info)  So I hope you Purchase Dont Starve Together if you can!

I've played DST for a really long time, like a really REALLY long time. I have over 300 hours on it and it's probably my most played game in my entire steam inventory. That being said, this game is PHENOMENAL. The art style is to die for, the themes for when you get into boss fights, ambient music, how each character has their own instrument are incredible. There are so many little nuances that Klei inserts into the game that makes me revere it so highly, it's the small attention to detail in the game that makes it so fantastic.   This game has quite a bit of a learning curve. You'll start out, and try to survive (probably rather unsuccessfully) and learn about what different mobs do, what certain structures do, which ones to build, and so forth. The beauty in this game is within its learning curve. It's designed for you to learn from your mistakes in a comical world where at first nearly everything can kill you, it can almost be discouraging. This matters so much however once you reach the point where you can actually survive. The amount of reward you feel, the amount of work that's paid off is immense and it feels as though now that you've explored the game intimately enough you can really have some fun. Essentially, what I'm trying to say is that unlike other games where the player grinds to try to achieve something and feel successful, the fun for DST is experiencing and learning curve, as well as the payoff in the end. Even after you can survive, there's much more to do! There are boss fights and caves and the ruins, all things where the game continues to challenge the player.  With all this being said, hats off to you Klei. I've been with you since day 1, and you made a hell of a game.

I buyed the game to play with my friends, a lot of funny things happen, sometimes we achieve a good thing, sometimes we just die and load the old save so we didn't make any mistake again (we still make it anyway), we even want to make some different "play mode" for ourselves and make our own rules.  Despite all that happiness, i've never play this game alone, like this game is not my type actually, but with a friend, this game could is really fun.  To fully enjoy this game, i recommend you to have a friends first, so your early game will be easier and you have someone to blame with if you fucked up a thing. I have many hours on this game, and for good reason! Don't Starve Together is a fantastic standalone expansion to the first game Don't Starve (also wonderful, I have both!). A fun way to test your skills on putting up your dukes against the rest of a randomly-generated world filled with monsters, magic, and your friends! Constantly being updated, the developers are very invested in this game and may be for quite a while. Servers can hold many, many people, though I do recommend a superior internet source as it may be a bit laggy otherwise. But don't worry, it's not unbearable unless you have many people on a single server. All in all, I completely recommend this game. Fun for hours with friends and even strangers, one of the best games I've seen in a long time!

Don't starve together is a challenging multiplayer survival game, art work looks amazing and great fun with friends.   This game is very addictive and a amazing game experience due to the many elements they put into the making of this game.   The open world aspect of the game allows its players to explore and manipulate an ever-changing world how they like, no map is the same.  Unforgiving multiplayer strategy sandbox game where every action you make can affect your future game play.   If you die then don't worry as you come back as a ghost and then can annoy everyone around you :)  Open world, survival and multiplayer gets my vote every time :)  The price of £10:99 also Includes an extra copy of Don't Starve Together. Send it to a friend!  One of the best coop games i have played and would recommend you buy.

This game is perfect for anyone who enjoys farming, in a group setting. I never get tired of starting from the beginning, just so I can farm everything all over again! I can play with my friends while I scour the wilderness for food and supplies, and I love to see how many seasons I can survive, as I get more experience. There are definitely tricks to this trade, but playing with other people in the servers can help newcomers learn the ropes! Don't be afraid to press "Y", and type what you need into the chat; you might be surprised at how helpful your companions can be.

I have played this game more than any other game I have on Steam. For those who like collecting, building, searching, and figuring things out in a sandbox world, this is one of those definitive games of the genre. And playing with friends makes it so much more fun. Surviving seasons and monsters together is thrilling. There's such a depth and richness to the game, and it's awesome that the developers continue to improve it with tweaks and new content regularly. There's a tremendous amount of replaybility to the game. I know I'll  be playing it for a long time to come.

TL;DR review: this is a 10/10 masterpiece and sits near the top of the best all-time indie and survival genres. If you don't have the game and it is on sale, buy it. If it's not on sale, it's still underpriced, and well worth the cost. I'll continue a more detailed review below.  The outstanding singeplayer "Don't Starve" is strengthened even more with the addition of multiplayer, here in the "Don't Starve Together" variation. If I were asked to name a great game that becomes even better with friends, this would probably be my top recommendation.  As you can see from the images, the art style is rather dark, yet charming. This theme remains consistent throughout all aspects of the game, combining perfectly to impress audiences of all ages and aesthetic preferences. Despite having the semblance of a nice little relaxing game to play, the game does not hold your hand, and provides minimal guidance.  You are thrown into the wilderness with many challenges and dangers to face. Don't expect to do well without a lot of trial-and-error. And even after you've figured out how to make light and avoid dying in the darkness, how to hunt, gather, farm, and cook enough food to maintain your hunger for a little while longer, the game will throw new challenges in your face that you probably will not be ready for.  The gameplay is deceptively simple -- gather supplies, build structures, craft equipment, flee from or fight monsters, and ultimately, survive. This pairs perfectly with the game's unique form of difficulty. The game does not seem so difficult until a new problem appears and you have to figure out how to solve it. When faced with that problem, your survival will be determined by a few principles: having enough knowledge of the game to deal with the problem effectively, anticipating and preparing for this problem, and either being creative enough or improvising to solve this problem. To a lesser extent, the game does have a small mechanical skillgap, but the mechanics are simple for the most part. The only real mechanical challenge will be learning how monsters move and determining when to attack, dodge, and run from them.  Ultimately, the game will push both your character and you to your limits. Even when you get lucky, you'll probably still face an exhilirating near-death experience. Otherwise you'll die and learn new things about the game, and be better prepared to face that challenge in the future.   Don't Starve is on par with a small list of masterpiece games that beat you down for your mistakes without making it feel like the game cheated you. Each mistake being preventable, your blunders truly feel like opportunities to learn how to build yourself back up later on.

This game was not what I expected. Due to the art style and type of game, I expected it to be an overhead version of Minecraft or Terraria. A simple, easy kid's game that you dink around in with your friends.  This is not that game. Do not get this game if that's what you're looking for. Go look at Unturned if that's what you want. This is an extremely diffficult strategy game. It's fun as a kind of game when you want to see "How many times can my buddies and I fuck this up before we get bored?" but is also entertaining as a pretty serious strategy game you spend hours forming. Ride or die, man. You'd think three hours is enough time to get a handle and start playing seriously and lasting for seasons at a time. My girlfriend and I still die within three days. This game is a monster, but I'll beat it. I got this on sale cause I'm broke, but if you're into this kind of game, get it full price.

This game is pretty good. All the characters have their own unique abilities and perks, and theres a lot to learn about the Don't Starve world. There can be many challenges when you play, and it has a decently high skill cap. Its a great survival game and once you git gud there can be many fun things to do in the game (ruins, speedruns, base building). I wouldn't recommend this game for everyone, because it can be pretty boring at first if you dont know much about the game and keep dying. However, if u commit to learning the game it might be more enjoyable.

Great game but one issue consistently annoys me and causes me to die.  Campfires and hitboxes are really messy and need work. You'll place a campfire when it's highlighted green but I won't place sometimes. The solution is to play the game slowly and be careful. As I want to have a thrilling game, I refuse to play at the dreadfully slow rate the game wants you to.  Edit: Just generated a world that I couldn't find saplings or twigs in and died first night due to inablity to make light. Very rare bug, but this needs fixed. Games that force you into close calls can't randomly kill you.  TLDR; Great game but will unfairly screw you over if you don't play slowly, so game's not for everyone.  Give it a go if enjoy hardcore resource-based survival games.

As a bonus, you also get a free gift copy so that you can play it with a buddy!

This game is definitely not easy, it'll be difficult to learn and master to kite and kill enemies. Be prepared to die a lot at the beginning, you can rollback your world 1 day if you're playing alone to prevent resetting your world or use commands.  There is 4 seasons with their own unique bosses with powerful and interesting boss specific drops. There is also raid bosses that are very difficult, they can be killed alone but will be extremely difficult at the beginning. Each session also has it's own challenges, such as overheating during summer, frog rain in spring, freezing during winter, etc. which requires you to acquire particular items in order to survive.  The gardening system (farms) are useful to have in order to grow crops which you'll require for unique dishes made using the crock pot (Don't use the basic farm, use the advanced one). crops such as the dragon fruit can be used to make one of the best source of healing in the game, but retrieving the crop you want is difficult as the fruit/veg that appears will be random and certain fruit/veg have a higher chance to appear compared to other ones making it difficult to retrieve certain fruits and vegetables you want. Once you retrieve the crop you want, I'd recommend feeding it to the bird in the cage to get that fruit/vegs seeds in order to grow it.   The combat system will be difficult to master, you have to learn to kit enemies which is moving and dodging pretty much. You get great satisfaction when you learn to kill more difficult stuff.   Each season (Autumn, Spring, Spring, Summer) has it's own difficulty, Summer and Winter being the most difficult.   Each character have their own unique perks and advantages and disadvantages which change the way you would play them in comparison to the other characters, for example (one of the characters cannot sleep, two are seen as monsters meaning neutral creatures are hostile, one can only eat meat based food only, etc.) Certain characters are much more efficient at doing another characters role, I'd recommend testing each character to see which suits your play style. (I recommend Wilson during the start to learn the game, unless you looked at guides)     You can retrieve mods that improve on the UI, provide you with a mini map, display your temperature and more. There is mods that add new characters, biomes, structure and more as well. These can be used to make the game easier or more difficult. (Be aware that mods can be out of date)  Cooking foods is certainly fun, but certain foods are much more efficient at providing health, sanity and/or hunger due to the value they provide and how much more easier and efficient they are to make. Certain foods have effects such as raising your temperature. I recommend knowing different types of foods rather than learning what's the best for restoring certain stats.   There is much more to say about how great this game is.

I've almost played 50 hours of Don't Starve Together and can safely say that I recommend it for those who like a sandbox/survival feel. The game itself is more enjoyable with a friend, but this doesn't stop you from enjoying it on your own. Working together as a team is a good thing in this game, and each season brings on new challenges and creatures, so you're always on the go strategising your next move! It's always been fun to talk about the equipment you may need or where a good position to set up camp is. Coming back to the single player aspect, You can play on your own in Don't Starve Together, just as you can in Don't Starve, and I made the misake of purchasing Don't Starve before Don't Starve Together, thinking they were essentually two different offers. They're not, so I would also recommend not purchacing Don't Starve as there's no real point. Also, the game has such a unique/beautiful art style, it definetly helps seperate the game from others that are alike in my opinion. A very well designed and thought out game. Love it.

Don't Starve Together is a wonderful multiplayer survival game that combines a simple premise with goofy humor in an insane world.  If the basic strategy elements don't keep you invested, the absurd situations and creatures you encounter will almost certainly motivate you to want to survive another day in order to continue your exploration of the Don't Starve universe.

Hi!  Don't starve together allows you to challenge yourself with a couple of friends. It really adds a new dimension to the original. I can only recommend it.
If you enjoyed the original and have friends to play with this game is well worth it. If you're planning to play alone though I would stick with the original as all the bosses have buffed health.

Don't Starve Together is definitely an uncompromising survival game, which will weed out the weak and those who aren't able to learn how to prepare for and adapt to the changes the seasons will bring. Yet with cooperation and planning, the game can be quite enjoyable and the seasonal events really spice things up, such as the Forge which puts 6 players in an arena against waves of enemies, each character fulfilling a different role to achieve success. The art style is fun, even cute, and the feel  or struggle of collecting sticks and stones to eventually constructing a fortress against the seasons and beasts (if you're smart, and maybe a bit lucky) with friends or just people online is rewarding.
Honestly, it's the Dark Souls of survival games.

Hello! I might not have many hours in this game compared to other ones but... ya know what??? It was fun. Very fun. Playing for the first time with your friends trying to understand what is going on. Creating a bunch of worlds just to die and create a new one. Having your cellphone next to you in case you need to quickly search something on the wikia. Inviting more friends to come and play together. Dying again. Usually, I get pretty pissed off when I die but in this game, its just funny. Dying of stupid ways. But atleast you know how you die and how you can escape that death :) I recommend this game to everyone who enjoys survival games (and to be honest, at first, this game can be a little spooky). Also, don't forget to give the extra copy to a close friend so that you can play together :D

The don't starve games are by far some of the best survival games around. The amount of thought and creativity that went into this game is incredible. There are so many details - animals that are aggressive only in their mating season, different clothing and ingestion needs per season, the vast amount of items and landscapes and craftables. If you enjoy survival games that are far more detailed than "eat, sleep, and fight" then you will love don't starve.

Don't Starve Together (DST) is one of the most unique and stylistic survival games out there. Whilst most of the crafting-survival genre tend to blend together gameplay wise, with only one or two elements seperating them from others, DST takes it in a whole new direction. Using the same gameplay and artstyle of the original game, it expands on it by including the Reign of Giants DLC and occasional special events.  With its sprite-based, drawn isometric artstyle, you'll see no end of the creative, horrifying, or creatively horrifying creatures and landscapes that this world has to offer.
Personally one of my favourite games. Difficult, but balanced survival - if you die, it's your fault.

9 / 10  These day its hard to find good companies, but Klei is the best. They actually care about their games and community, and the put so much hard work and love into this game, that even if it would be bad, i would give them good review. But the thing is, its amazing. Ive never liked survival games, because they always felt flat. Like when you had some food and water, all other stuff was just boring and all the same, there just wasnt anything to do and nothing interesting. But this games takes you into the story, you never feel bored because theres always something new behind the corner, even after 60 hours i have seen basically nothing. So much stuff, and everything looks fun and cool, drawing is amazing in this game, quite frankly, i dont even know about any cons. Its an amazing game, and with all the events, updates, and the fact that when you buy the game you get extra copy, theres nothing bad to say about it. Only one warning, this game is hard, and i mean really fucking HARD. It may be the hardest game ive played, but even though this games fuck you like your 50 year old uncle, you just want more. Its just terrific.

However, you can't vote kick players or force start games; if you got an afk person in your Forge or Gorge server, you won't be playing until they are back on. There are lots of things needed to be improved for it to become a good multiplayer game, though the game itself is very fun.

You start with nothing, in the wilderness, with your friends. Sooner or later you end your life, possibly surrounded by stuff you have built and invented, in the wilderness, with your friends, who are already dead or about to die.  Between those certain points, you hunt for food, buildingmaterials, firewood and more food. You also cook, invent things to cook better food and to store food, and try to fins more fuel for your inventions that help you cook. And then you die. Again. And you promise yourself never to play this stupid game again. Just one more try, and then  you'll never do it again... for real this time... really....
